From shriramadhas at gmail.com  Fri Dec  1 01:01:31 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Mark Shuttleworth on Free Software and Education
Message-ID: <1164915091.5085.44.camel@amachu-laptop>

Hi all,

Mark Shuttle worth came on IRC to answer Ubuntu user's question Ubuntu
Open Week. Here is what he had to share on Free Software in Education...

---------------------------------
sabdfl(18:29:57) amachu: QUESTION: Education sector the real arena where
Ubuntu can prove decisive.. Mark, how do compare with Microsoft's
educational suites with Edubuntu?  

sabdfl:         I think the best thing that free software does in
education is
DIVERSITY  

sabdfl:         we don't (yet) have the best word processor  

sabdfl:         though we have at least three *pretty good* ones  

sabdfl:         what we do have is a huge spectrum of tools  sabdflfor
all
sorts of disciplines  

sabdfl:         music, art, maths, physics, statistics, programming,
design  

sabdfl:         you name it  sabdfland those tools are free of charge  

sabdfl:         and OPEN  

sabdfl:         you can see how the tools work  sabdfland you can shape
them  

sabdfl:         that's a treasure chest for education  

sabdfl:         especially in places where the kids are often smarter
than the
teachers  

sabdfl:         so, we should focus on that

http://www.tonyyarusso.is-a-geek.com/irclogs/openweek/%
23ubuntu-classroom.html

----------------------------------------

Shuttleworth on Ubuntu Locoteams:
https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-tam/2006-November/000039.html

On 30-Nov-06, at 7:04 PM, S.Ramaswamy wrote:

> to hog resources affecting the performance of other VMs. I am not sure
> how you ensure resource hogging does not happen with Xen

technically xen supports memory quotas, and you cant exceed the  
quota. But in practice, nothing is perfect - and however sincere the  
hoster is, he is tempted to get more bang for his buck and squeezes  
in too many vpns on one server - and everything goes phut.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Dec  1 09:29:01 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Dec  1 09:29:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Monthly reminder: mailing list guidelines
Message-ID: <327503.5506.qm@web50212.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

Please don't reply to this e-mail. If you would like
to update it, do it here:

  http://chennailug.org/guidelines

1. Use a proper subject line.

2. Do not troll in the mailing list

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_troll

3. Use [OT] for off-topic, non-technical discussions.
But, don't misuse this to start flame wars or to troll
in the mailing list.

4. Do not top-post:

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Top-posting

Example of a top-post:

Because it messes up the order in which
people normally read text.
> > Why is top-posting
> > such a bad thing?
Top-posting.
> > What is the most
> > annoying thing in e-mail?

Always use bottom-posting.

> What is your name ?
My name is ILUGC.

5. Do not over-quote:

Example of an over-quote:

>>> On Friday you said
>>> blah blah blah
>> On Saturday you said
>> foo foo foo
> On Sunday you said
> foobar

6. Do not post HTML messages

7. Do not recycle messages

8. Do not send attachments

9. Do not attach obnoxious, nonsensical legal
disclaimers. If your company uses disclaimers, don't
use your company ID for the mailing list.

10. Do not reply to a digest. (If you are in digest
mode and want to reply to a post use ILUGC Gmane blog
interface.

Link:
http://blog.gmane.org/gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc

11. Search for answers for your questions/problems in
google.com or any other search engine before posting
your query to the mailing list.

If any of the above are not clear to you, Please read
the detailed list guidelines:

Link:
http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

12. Do not post messages in all capital letters. Mails
in CAPS is considered rude and is similar to shouting
during a conversation.

13. If you or your company is into GNU/Linux
migration, or you want help into GNU/Linux migration,
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/GNU_Linux_migration

14. If you are looking for GNU/Linux distro CDs please
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/CDs_for_Grab

15. Following these guidelines could be helpful
http://people.debian.org/~enrico/dcg/

16. Don't send season's greetings or birthday invites
to the group. Its not mailing list etiquette.

We must use the above guidelines to maintain better
readability, proper archives, efficient bandwidth
usage, etc. 


 
____________________________________________________________________________________
Do you Yahoo!?
Everyone is raving about the all-new Yahoo! Mail beta.
http://new.mail.yahoo.com

> and Does python have a IDE

yes - idle, eric3 and about 20 others - and eclipse and emacs for the  
experts

> like Visual Basic or .Net?

not exactly - if you use wxPython, boa constructor is an all  
encompassing IDE - and python for doze has some nifty ides also

But the point is that foss programming is not like doze programming.  
The whole approach is different - here we dont blindly drag and drop.  
we try to understand what we are doing. So dont expect things to be  
'like' the doze equivalents.

your .py module.

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Fri Dec  1 11:04:13 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Fri Dec  1 11:04:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] ASP.NET vs. PHP5
Message-ID: <1092.61.247.255.57.1164951253.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

On 1-Dec-06, at 8:40 PM, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:

>> On the other hand, When I am this big corporate and looking for a RAD
>> framework, where some 50 people with decent programming skills can
>> work on this mammoth web application where deadline is the key, Well,
>> I will go for ASP.Net.  Coupled with Visual Studio.Net, it sure is an
>> awesome framework to work on. The level of debugging and the event
>> driven layer to web development, inbuilt webcontrols, all make things
>> simpler for programmers and let them write less code and hence lesser
>> bugs.

>in short, you propose ASP.net as a substitute for getting/training
>good programmers and taking the effort to develop a team with good
>programming practices, or in a word, as a substitute for hard work -
>as for me, I believe there is no substitute for hard work.

Do you really think PHP requires better coding skills than .NET? Anyone
with a half a brain can start coding in PHP in a day's time... .NET / J2EE
has a steeper learning curve.

But once you learn .NET or J2EE, you can start working with them and use
the advanced features easily. with PHP, you will have to reinvent the
wheel.

Frankly, comparing ASP.NET to PHP5 is equivalent to comparing C++ with
GWBasic - that is, there is no comparison.

ASP.NET is far more mature than PHP in every sense. It is better to
compare ASP.NET with Java/J2EE than with PHP.

But since we are comparing ASP.NET to PHP, some points that come to mind:

- the ASP.NET tools are better and are available free (Visual Web
Developer Express is available free and so also MS Expression Designer).

- The width and depth of the functions available in the libraries which
form part of .NET / Java and J2EE cannot be matched by PHP.

- ASP.NET / J2EE has support for writing layers of business logic which
can then be reused across applications (both web and desktop), across
machine boundaries etc. If you write your routines in PHP, you cannot
really reuse them in anything other than PHP web solutions - you cannot
have desktop applications using the same code.

- Webservices / remoting / RMI etc... Try doing these properly in PHP.

- Speed of execution is better because of compiled code (you can argue
about Zend but it is hard to beat ASP.NET / Java in speed)

That is just a few points.. there are many, many more points which can be
mentioned.

But having said that, PHP is far easier to code in..and if you want
something developed quickly, and this something is not too complex, then
it is best done in PHP. Hosting a PHP solution is easier and much cheaper.
So for most cases, PHP is a good option.

Thanks,
PK

i wasnt saying that - i was only commenting on the OP's statement  
that if his programmers werent too good he would go for asp.net. If  
your programmers are not too good - the code will be crappy  
regardless of the language/platform you use.

Subject: [Ilugc] C/C++ and Perl skilled professionals required
Message-ID: <9c0ef0220611302227x74ba2515q4475464935c5dc95@mail.gmail.com>

Hi All

I am seeking C/C++ and Perl skilled professionals who have minimum 2 years
hands-on experience working on any one of the following areas:-  Network
protocols (TCP/IP, POP3), telecom protocols (SS7, CDMA, TCAP, GSM, GPRS),
Soft Switches, VoIP, SIP, Lex/YACC, Unix Internals, Kernels, Device Drivers,
Set-Top-Box, DTH and so on

Minimum experience is 2 year and maximum experience may be 12 years.

Bachelor in Engineering or Masters in Computer Applications is a Must.
Exceptional project experience is a definite requirement so those
B.Sc(Computer Science, Maths) graduates who have worked on cutting
edge
technologies may be considered.

please reply with resume to albert.faria@gmail.com

From karthick.ramachandran at gmail.com  Fri Dec  1 15:14:06 2006
From: karthick.ramachandran at gmail.com (Karthick R)
Date: Fri Dec  1 15:14:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] ASP.NET vs. PHP5
In-Reply-To: <CDD38B02-ACF5-434E-96FB-7C14545D9FB5@thenilgiris.com>
References: <69621d830611271037v6062d37bh604763c01e95b06@mail.gmail.com>
	<7e0d5bce0611300710l50434adau4a8fdffb9f221839@mail.gmail.com>
	<CDD38B02-ACF5-434E-96FB-7C14545D9FB5@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <7e0d5bce0612010144u4f30dfv7ef2dc5c55fd26c7@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/1/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
> in short, you propose ASP.net as a substitute for getting/training
> good programmers and taking the effort to develop a team with good
> programming practices, or in a word, as a substitute for hard work -
> as for me, I believe there is no substitute for hard work.

i agree with you on there is no substitute for hard work. What I am
trying to say here, is,  instead of spending time on reinventing the
wheel, one can concentrate on adding more functionalities and
enhancements to the existing application. Having said that, I am not
saying that it is not possible to write good OO programs in PHP. But
it is just that it demands more work from programmers.

> i was only commenting on the OP's statement
> that if his programmers werent too good he would go for asp.net. If
> your programmers are not too good - the code will be crappy
> regardless of the language/platform you use.

I agree again :). My personal belief is, the quality of programmers
required for writing "good" PHP applications should be really high.
The reason is PHP gives way too much space for committing errors. But
with ASP.Net, even a novice to that language can come up with a very
good program, because, the language doesn't give you much of "freedom"
to commit mistakes.

> Do you really think PHP requires better coding skills than .NET?

Yes "coding skills", PHP requires better coding skills, better than
what .Net requires. I agree that the learning curve is steep. But once
you get hold of the framework knowledge, you can start writing good
programs from the day one, without much of programming skills. The
reason is the amount of code you actually write for  developing
ASP.Net application is very less compared to PHP. That drastically
reduces the risk of bugs, manageability and puts the dependency more
on the process/application using which the program is developed than
on the person who is developing it.


-- 
Karthick R
http://puggy.symonds.net/~charisma

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Dec  1 16:45:30 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Dec  1 16:45:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Compeling Linux kernel
In-Reply-To: <d37948920611302308u2a71f4b3rf42d6747ff48b4f0@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <36267.94363.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- veeraa bose <veeraaexp@gmail.com> wrote:
> would i like to know what are the essential thing i
> have to inbulid or load
> as a module in kernel while compeling.i would like
> to learn each option in
> kernel.

Basically, block device, initrd support for ramdisk:

  CONFIG_BLK_DEV_RAM
  CONFIG_BLK_DEV_INITRD
 
SCSI support needs to be enabled:

  CONFIG_SCSI
  CONFIG_BLK_DEV_SD

Your filesystem support:

  CONFIG_EXT3_FS
  CONFIG_EXT2_FS

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

Philosophically speaking - I cannot always have what I want. But here
is the situation.
I am a pc assembler trying to promote linux with all I have and this
is one area I stumble upon. For new systems there is not much problem
because people go with broadband and there is no need for modems. For
old systems there are quite a lot of people who still rely on dialup.
I am trying to make people to switch to linux. But when it comes to
internal modems I am stuck. I can make somebody to spend 250Rs and
switch to linux because I can convince them that it is more secure and
there are no viruses. but making somebody spend 1500 is a tough call.
I know there are internal modems that are supported in linux. I just
dont know which all are available in our Indian market. That is the
area where I need help with.
Anoop

called unstable, it is much stable than many other stable distro.

Subject: [Ilugc] Internal modems with linux support
In-Reply-To: <406f1f3f0612010359t57418ebfl9b7b27edfb0b1b02@mail.gmail.com>

	<406f1f3f0611302240j22a21e30i3aab04ca73227d52@mail.gmail.com>
	<0C7F30FC-C62D-4C9B-B100-A7C4214A4CF6@thenilgiris.com>
	<406f1f3f0612010359t57418ebfl9b7b27edfb0b1b02@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <faaa5da00612022244y6cd5285cwe2fe506a8ab282e4@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/1/06, Anoop John <anoopjohn@gmail.com> wrote:
 But here is the situation.
> I am a pc assembler trying to promote linux with all I have and this
> is one area I stumble upon. For new systems there is not much problem
> because people go with broadband and there is no need for modems. For
> old systems there are quite a lot of people who still rely on dialup.
> I am trying to make people to switch to linux. But when it comes to
> internal modems I am stuck. I can make somebody to spend 250Rs and
> switch to linux because I can convince them that it is more secure and
> there are no viruses. but making somebody spend 1500 is a tough call.
> I know there are internal modems that are supported in linux. I just
> dont know which all are available in our Indian market. That is the
> area where I need help with.

all you need to do is get in touch with marvin stodolsky, the
linmodems maintainer at linmodems.org, you will get the procedure
which will be something like you run the diagnostic tool sent by them
, copy and return the output for receiving the correct driver for
making your existing softmodem( ! ) fully operational. incidentally,
it is indians like soumyendu sarkar who have developed the basic stuff
to make such linmodems too to work; there has been much development in
this field and it was thanks to marvstod(marvin stodolsky) that i
could get my agere systems modem to work on my acer 4152 NLCi laptop
to work !

you said QUOTE I can make somebody to spend 250Rs and
> switch to linux because I can convince them that it is more secure and
> there are no viruses. but making somebody spend 1500 is a tough call.UNQUOTE
HTH & , good luck .keep the list posted of your success or, otherwise.
From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Sun Dec  3 13:52:36 2006
From: toufeeqh at gmail.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Sun Dec  3 13:52:48 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
Message-ID: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>

I managed to snag a Linksys WRT54GS from a friend who returned from
the US recently. AS with all consumer electronics from the USA, this
one also runs on AC 120 V as input using a power adapter. I managed to
get a plug-in type 240V to 110V step down transformer from a local
electronics shop for the power adapter.

My problem is that when I used the transformer/adapter combo with the
router the power LED keeps blinking and does not come to the "constant
always on" state it's supposed to (as per the User Manual). The manual
asays that the power LED flashes when powered on and finally comes to
"rest" after self-disgnosis.

Googling didn't help as all "constant LED flashing" problems are
attributed to failed flashing of openwrt firmware.

I did try setting up static IP on one of my PC's and pinging the IP
address set in the router(192.168.1.1) but got no ACK's.

Now, here are my questions;
1. What's the best way to run US-centric electronics (routers etc) in
India ? What power-solutions do people use ?
2. Have other Linksys WRT54G users faced similar problems ?
3. How good is the Linksys support in chennai ? the website does give
me a chennai number which I'll be calling tomorrow (mon).

Thanks,
Toufeeq
PS: Not marked OT as the router runs Linux and will run the community
based openwrt once I get it to work.
-- 
blog @ http://toufeeq.net
From binand at gmail.com  Sun Dec  3 14:08:10 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Dec  3 14:08:21 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>

On 03/12/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
> 1. What's the best way to run US-centric electronics (routers etc) in
> India ? What power-solutions do people use ?

Routers etc. have SMPS units that are capable of handling input in
both 110V and 230V AC.

> 2. Have other Linksys WRT54G users faced similar problems ?

I'm a 3Com man myself. My OfficeConnect unit has been "serving" me for
couple of years now, both in India and abroad without any problems.

From manokaran at gmail.com  Sun Dec  3 15:38:36 2006
From: manokaran at gmail.com (Mano)
Date: Sun Dec  3 15:38:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7bf1bec50612030208s47d41e1cu6cc295d5bb7ba2a5@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/3/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
> I managed to snag a Linksys WRT54GS from a friend who returned from
> the US recently. AS with all consumer electronics from the USA, this
> one also runs on AC 120 V as input using a power adapter. I managed to
> get a plug-in type 240V to 110V step down transformer from a local
> electronics shop for the power adapter.

I dont think a simple step down transformer would help! In the US it
is 110V @ 60 hertz but here it is 220V @ 50 hertz. AFAIK, transformers
cannot change the num of cycles.

Tread with caution.... you might be frying your router!

regds,
mano

-- 
War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!
From mohan.tux at gmail.com  Sun Dec  3 18:19:14 2006
From: mohan.tux at gmail.com (Mohan Sundaram)
Date: Sun Dec  3 18:19:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <7bf1bec50612030208s47d41e1cu6cc295d5bb7ba2a5@mail.gmail.com>

	<7bf1bec50612030208s47d41e1cu6cc295d5bb7ba2a5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4572C7CA.4010303@gmail.com>

Mano wrote:
> On 12/3/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
>> I managed to snag a Linksys WRT54GS from a friend who returned from
>> the US recently. AS with all consumer electronics from the USA, this
>> one also runs on AC 120 V as input using a power adapter. I managed to
>> get a plug-in type 240V to 110V step down transformer from a local
>> electronics shop for the power adapter.
> 
> I dont think a simple step down transformer would help! In the US it
> is 110V @ 60 hertz but here it is 220V @ 50 hertz. AFAIK, transformers
> cannot change the num of cycles.
> 
> Tread with caution.... you might be frying your router!
> 
> regds,
> mano
> 
I've used a 4/5 Linksys wireless and wired router boxes with such 
convertors for 4 years now. Works fine. The frequency does not matter as 
the system ultimately runs on DC (and the power supplies do not refuse 
to rectify 50Hz AC -:)). I'm stumped as to why it is not working.

It would be a good idea to check the output of the convertor. If it is 
low, then the output to the router would be below acceptable levels - 
possibly giving rise to your problem.

Mohan

Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340612030455m4317241qa392ce3ea1d64758@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
	<7bf1bec50612030208s47d41e1cu6cc295d5bb7ba2a5@mail.gmail.com>

Message-ID: <a8f990120612030528u7a027c7at8f089b57f7572c35@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/3/06, Toufeeq Hussain <toufeeqh@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>
> > It would be a good idea to check the output of the convertor. If it is
> > low, then the output to the router would be below acceptable levels -
> > possibly giving rise to your problem.
> >
>
> The output from the transformer or the adapter is not low. I've re-checked
> that.
> I'll mostly be trying out a 220V power adapter which gives 12 V DC o/p
> instead of using the step down transformer.
>
> Hi Toufeeq,
                  I've run a Linksys WRT54GS (US model, very similar to the
WRT54G)
in Chennai with a Shah Electronics 220v->110v converter and the stock
Linksys
wall-wart. It works just fine, and doesn't depend on the AC mains frequency.
However, the wall-wart may run hotter or get fried prematurely because of 50
Hz -
its impedance is lower at 50 Hz. I didn't run into any probs and was able to
flash mine with OpenWRT and play with it for a few hours.

    My guess is that your WRT54G may have already been through a bad
reflashing attempt and returned to the store, which then sold it back
(retailers
like Fry's Electronics at Sunnyvale routinely do this, and they're legally
allowed to do it as long as it is clearly marked as a return). The full
warranty is usually available in all such cases, but that's not much comfort
when you're sitting here.

   I believe there are ways to recover and reflash a WRT54G when it's
blinking
red - it still has an intact boot block, and has a fallback tftp-based
reflash
procedure for this case. Do a Google search for details - BAWUG or Seattle
Wireless should have the details on their Wiki(s). There are also ways to
use
a JTAG header to recover, but that requires some soldering and similar
stuff.

-Siva

did u try to ping the ip address or ping the host name , if you  ping the ip
, then try the hostname , maybe its a dns issue.

and one more thing , if you are able to pingthe serve , which means there is
already a route to the server without the proxy , then why do you need to
use proxy ? Or are you mentioning your gateway as the serve ??

From praveen at symonds.net  Sun Dec  3 23:25:05 2006
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Sun Dec  3 23:26:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <45730F79.3050406@symonds.net>

Toufeeq Hussain wrote:

> I managed to snag a Linksys WRT54GS from a friend who returned from
> the US recently. AS with all consumer electronics from the USA, this
> one also runs on AC 120 V as input using a power adapter. I managed to
> get a plug-in type 240V to 110V step down transformer from a local
> electronics shop for the power adapter.

I have a few Linksys routers. But I am not using the step down
transformer. Most of the Linksys models take 12V DC (Max 1A). I bought a
few SMPS (looks similar to Laptop charger but much smaller in size) of
12V/1-2A. I keep away from transformers because they are bulky and
produce some weird sound some times. SP Road in Bangalore has very good
SMPS collection of this sort. Maybe Ritchie Road should also carry some.

Regards -
Praveen.

Thanks for the tip. That should work for an existing modem. I am
talking about buying a new internal modem that could possibly work out
of the box. For example the old motorola sm56 had motorola support
till suse 9. I think they pulled out of the softmodem business now. I
know that Lucent and conextant has linmodem chipsets. I just dont know
which brand these linmodems appear in the market as. Say, if they come
in Mercury Internal modems then I can just buy mercury internal modems
and plug and play with the driver installed. So if any of you guys
know any of the brands under which linmodems come in Indian market
then that would be great.

Anoop

> , copy and return the output for receiving the correct driver for
> making your existing softmodem( ! ) fully operational. incidentally,
> it is indians like soumyendu sarkar who have developed the basic stuff
> to make such linmodems too to work; there has been much development in
> this field and it was thanks to marvstod(marvin stodolsky) that i
> could get my agere systems modem to work on my acer 4152 NLCi laptop
> to work !
>
> you said QUOTE I can make somebody to spend 250Rs and
> > switch to linux because I can convince them that it is more secure and
> > there are no viruses. but making somebody spend 1500 is a tough call.UNQUOTE
> HTH & , good luck .keep the list posted of your success or, otherwise.

From saravanan.raju at gmail.com  Mon Dec  4 08:55:34 2006
From: saravanan.raju at gmail.com (Saravanan Raju)
Date: Mon Dec  4 08:55:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <b40308c60612031925w24305b75o9bbfad126129e00a@mail.gmail.com>

> I managed to snag a Linksys WRT54GS from a friend who returned from
> the US recently. AS with all consumer electronics from the USA, this
> one also runs on AC 120 V as input using a power adapter.

Not that you missed, but I am surprised your Linksys WRT54GS did not
ship with a universal power adaptor. I have bunch of WRT54Gs (NOT GS)
and all of them do 110 AND 240 AC.

> I managed to
> get a plug-in type 240V to 110V step down transformer from a local
> electronics shop for the power adapter.
>
> My problem is that when I used the transformer/adapter combo with the
> router the power LED keeps blinking and does not come to the "constant
> always on" state it's supposed to (as per the User Manual). The manual
> asays that the power LED flashes when powered on and finally comes to
> "rest" after self-disgnosis.

You have to take this with dollops of salt and I do not how the
internal works with this Linksys router, but the equipments that I
have handled will not "rest" if the polarity of the AC terminals are
swapped.

<snip>

> Now, here are my questions;
> 1. What's the best way to run US-centric electronics (routers etc) in
> India ? What power-solutions do people use ?

The routers (and other gizmos) shipped with universal power adaptors.
The only precaution I take is to draw power from a decent UPS.

> 2. Have other Linksys WRT54G users faced similar problems ?

Nope.

<snip>

> PS: Not marked OT as the router runs Linux and will run the community
> based openwrt once I get it to work.

Welcome aboard :)

Best,
Saravanan

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Mon Dec  4 12:50:25 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Mon Dec  4 12:54:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>	<b40308c60612031925w24305b75o9bbfad126129e00a@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612031941s21d6e6eex22749bbfbee74cfa@mail.gmail.com>	<5f67d8bb0612032249u67c9e4e3k72b3786c813fc700@mail.gmail.com>
	<70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4573CC39.5010807@gmail.com>

Ingeneur wrote:
>> In proper wiring phase will be in right side and neutral will be in
>> left side of a plug point. May be he is refering that.
> I guessed that as well, but I never knew they mattered when you plug
> in a supply! Shame on my EE knowledge!
> 
IMHO, you need not feel shame. Think of this practical situation: when 
you plug in you mobile phone recharger, do you mind how you plug it in? 
i.e. do you mind which is phase and neutral in the pin and the plug hole 
? Polarities matter only in DC power sources, or when a device is 
designed to consume DC power. But in a AC power supply, anyways you 
current and voltage are swinging from negative to positive max and back, 
i.e. its varying with time.

Am afraid, from my vanishing knowledge of EE, that the problem comes 
during the conversion of AC to DC, i.e. rectification that some 
converters are designed such that they do not produce the proper 
polarity when you change the phase and neutral (which I think, should 
not be the way).

Correct me if am wrong somewhere, especially the EE people of IIT in 
this list ;)

-- 
With Regards

Parthan (TechnoFreak)

.   A Proud GNU/Linux User and Ubuntero
.0.
..0 [Web] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Parthan
000 [Blog]http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com

From praveen at symonds.net  Mon Dec  4 13:22:51 2006
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Mon Dec  4 13:23:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>	<b40308c60612031925w24305b75o9bbfad126129e00a@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612031941s21d6e6eex22749bbfbee74cfa@mail.gmail.com>	<5f67d8bb0612032249u67c9e4e3k72b3786c813fc700@mail.gmail.com>
	<70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4573D3D3.8060907@symonds.net>

Ingeneur wrote:
>> In proper wiring phase will be in right side and neutral will be in
>> left side of a plug point. May be he is refering that.
> I guessed that as well, but I never knew they mattered when you plug
> in a supply! Shame on my EE knowledge!

It is really not an issue how you plug to an AC source. Polarity is only
 for DC sources. In AC power systems, instead of the current flowing
continuously in one direction, it reverses many times per second. There
is no importance of polarity.

Praveen.

From krish.arava at gmail.com  Mon Dec  4 20:49:36 2006
From: krish.arava at gmail.com (krishna chaitanya arava)
Date: Mon Dec  4 20:49:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Problem connecting using wireless router
Message-ID: <feff2f50612040719u20eb1b44nf3134b59d9c29f27@mail.gmail.com>

I have one ADSL router to connect to the internet.
I usually connect my D-Link DI-524 wireless router to ADSL router so that we
can use my laptop and desktop together.

Few days ago the ADSL router was changed to new one. Ever since then I am
not able to connect my through my wireless router.

I have tried all the settings like changing MTU. But nothing works.
I can connect using the desktop but not using my wireless router.
Any clues on how to resolve this?

Thanks in advance.

regards,
A Chaitanya
From binand at gmail.com  Mon Dec  4 21:13:36 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Mon Dec  4 21:13:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Problem connecting using wireless router
In-Reply-To: <feff2f50612040719u20eb1b44nf3134b59d9c29f27@mail.gmail.com>
References: <feff2f50612040719u20eb1b44nf3134b59d9c29f27@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612040743m7b0e9b5eqdbeb4d4445680d55@mail.gmail.com>

On 04/12/06, krishna chaitanya arava <krish.arava@gmail.com> wrote:
> Few days ago the ADSL router was changed to new one. Ever since then I am
> not able to connect my through my wireless router.

Probably your VPI/VCI values changed. Check your desktop machine's
ADSL configuration for the new numbers and enter them in the router's
configuration.

If your desktop box is using Windows, the VPI/VCI values are commonly
shown in the number-to-dial box (if it says 0,32 then VPI = 0 and VCI
= 32), but could be just about anywhere in the custom ADSL connection
software.

Binand

In-Reply-To: <6593151E-B43D-4DF7-8B9E-8F8526D8DD02@thenilgiris.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>	<b40308c60612031925w24305b75o9bbfad126129e00a@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612031941s21d6e6eex22749bbfbee74cfa@mail.gmail.com>	<5f67d8bb0612032249u67c9e4e3k72b3786c813fc700@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>	<4573CC39.5010807@gmail.com>	<807C365D-1969-4F79-943F-2D26C7737786@thenilgiris.com>	<70106e0b0612041907w688d47f7nfa257ab721ea212@mail.gmail.com>
	<6593151E-B43D-4DF7-8B9E-8F8526D8DD02@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <4574F734.7060406@symonds.net>

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:

> On 05-Dec-06, at 8:37 AM, Ingeneur wrote:
> 
>>> try plugging in an immersion heater or stove with the pins reversed
>>> and see what happens
>> I just didn't want to answer, but couldn't help! Does immersion heater
>> or stove rectify the supply? I haven't any knowledge of these
>> appliances.
> 
> you will get a shock - also from other electrical appliances that are
> cross wired - i dont know the theory behind, but i have got shocks

Immersion heaters or stoves don't care about polarity. The shock might
have been because of the insulation breakage due to usage with
inadequate or no water. I have used immersion heaters for four years in
my hostel lives at MIT. It used to have just two pins which allows the
possibility of swapping polarities. I never got a shock in my life. The
same applies to the stoves as well. Polarity is not an issue for single
phase AC devices.

Praveen.

From manokaran at gmail.com  Tue Dec  5 10:37:39 2006
From: manokaran at gmail.com (Mano)
Date: Tue Dec  5 10:37:49 2006
Subject: [OT]Re: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <93F28444-6DA7-4180-ADF2-A16E8D28325C@thenilgiris.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>
	<70106e0b0612031941s21d6e6eex22749bbfbee74cfa@mail.gmail.com>
	<5f67d8bb0612032249u67c9e4e3k72b3786c813fc700@mail.gmail.com>
	<70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>
	<4573CC39.5010807@gmail.com>
	<807C365D-1969-4F79-943F-2D26C7737786@thenilgiris.com>
	<70106e0b0612041907w688d47f7nfa257ab721ea212@mail.gmail.com>
	<6593151E-B43D-4DF7-8B9E-8F8526D8DD02@thenilgiris.com>
	<4574F734.7060406@symonds.net>
	<93F28444-6DA7-4180-ADF2-A16E8D28325C@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <7bf1bec50612042107l468c59c3r4240ef7a3d922382@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/5/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
> i have got shocks from fridges, microwave ovens and ordinary stoves -
> when cross-wired, tester will glow when touching a metal part. Again,
> I dont know the theory - but i have felt the pain ;-)

Usually the phase is connected through the switch and the neutral
directly to the device. SO when the switch is OFF there is no power
supply to the device. When it is done otherwise, the phase is
connected directly with the device and even when the switch is OFF
there is power in the device (eddy loss). So when you touch it you
close the circuit to the ground and get a shock. Again, this can
happen only if the insulation in the device is not proper.

regards,
mano

















-- 
War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Dec  5 10:41:06 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Dec  5 10:41:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Help with Fluxbox.
In-Reply-To: <4574F2D8.30108@midascomm.com>
References: <4574F2D8.30108@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <20061205051106.GB31745@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Tue, Dec 05, 2006 at 09:47:28AM +0530, Sivaram Kannan wrote:
> 
> Hi all,
> 
> I was trying to install and run the latest fluxbox version 1.0 rc2. When 
> I try to run the installed fluxbox it is saying,
> "cannot connet to the X server". i edited the xinitrc file with the line 
> "exec fluxbox", gave startx and still the got the
> same error.
> 
> Can someone help me out with this please?

Are you using any chooser program like xdm/kdm/gdm/wdm?

If so, selecting fluxbox in the dropdown menu(if it has it) will solve.

If instead you start X manually then, you need .xinitrc for invoking your favorite window manager.

You can try giving the full path of fluxbox in your exec command.

Of course if you start fluxbox from the console, you will get this error but then I think you know that already. :)

Best,
Girish

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> 
> On 05-Dec-06, at 10:06 AM, Praveen Kumar wrote:
> 
>>> you will get a shock - also from other electrical appliances that are
>>> cross wired - i dont know the theory behind, but i have got shocks
>>
>> Immersion heaters or stoves don't care about polarity. The shock might
>> have been because of the insulation breakage due to usage with
>> inadequate or no water. I have used immersion heaters for four years in
>> my hostel lives at MIT. It used to have just two pins which allows the
>> possibility of swapping polarities. I never got a shock in my life. The
>> same applies to the stoves as well. Polarity is not an issue for single
>> phase AC devices.
> 
> i have got shocks from fridges, microwave ovens and ordinary stoves -
> when cross-wired, tester will glow when touching a metal part. Again, I
> dont know the theory - but i have felt the pain ;-)

The shock on the other devices were because of the improper
earth/ground. It is not because they are cross-wired as there is no
concept of cross-wiring in single phase AC (talking just about
live/phase and neutral terminals).

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_AC_power_plugs_and_sockets

When the theory is not known, it is better to ask for why is it so
rather than coming into some quick conclusion.

Praveen.

From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Tue Dec  5 11:07:56 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Tue Dec  5 11:09:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Help with Fluxbox.
In-Reply-To: <45750049.4060704@midascomm.com>
References: <4574F2D8.30108@midascomm.com>	<20061205051106.GB31745@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<45750049.4060704@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <457505B4.6020306@gopalarathnam.com>

Sivaram Kannan wrote:
>> Are you using any chooser program like xdm/kdm/gdm/wdm?
>>   
> yes, i am using gdm and it does not have it. i do not understand how to 
> make an entry to that.

Just create a file named ".xsession" in your home directory with execute 
permissions and add the line "exec /path/to/yourwm".

In GDM, choose the system default or something equivalent.  It'll run 
"$HOME/.xsession".

-- 
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

http://gopalarathnam.com/

Message-ID: <CA841075-6198-4152-A8C1-40FCE42027DE@thenilgiris.com>


On 05-Dec-06, at 10:41 AM, Praveen Kumar wrote:

> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_AC_power_plugs_and_sockets
>
> When the theory is not known, it is better to ask for why is it so
> rather than coming into some quick conclusion.

so what does this mean:

<quote>

Swapping live and neutral wires. In many countries this is not  
regarded as an error and it is perfectly feasible to design  
appliances such that they will be safe (e.g. by using double pole  
switches and protection devices) under this condition. However if  
appliances are intended for use only in countries that take care to  
avoid live/neutral swaps then they may have only a single pole switch  
which on live-neutral reversal will end up in the neutral wire,  
leaving portions of the device live at all times. This does not pose  
immediate danger but increases the risk of shock if there is another  
fault or if someone tries to work on the appliance without  
disconnecting it. For example if live and neutral have been swapped  
in lamps, the shell of the lamp base will be connected to the line,  
greatly increasing the risk of shock when changing light bulbs.

</quote>

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

You needn't login as root user. Do anything root should be doing by
prefixing with a sudo command. Password will be your password,
assuming you are the only user in the system

From tshrinivasan at gmail.com  Tue Dec  5 12:09:15 2006
From: tshrinivasan at gmail.com (Shrinivasan T)
Date: Tue Dec  5 12:09:28 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re:could't access the root account

Hi.

to add a user in ubuntu,

$sudo adduser <username>

The password is the first users password.

To create the user "root" and set a password

$sudo passwd root

now you are setting the password for root.

Can any ubuntu fans tell me why ubuntu follows this thing?
Is ubuntu is going to become a single user OS?
or it hates the root user?

regards,
T.Shrinivasan
From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Tue Dec  5 12:09:54 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Tue Dec  5 12:14:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re:could't access the root account
In-Reply-To: <992287.21238.qm@web7613.mail.in.yahoo.com>
References: <992287.21238.qm@web7613.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <4575143A.5000001@gmail.com>

Thanigairajan murugan wrote:
> yesterday i installed ubuntu 6.06 .1 sucessfully.
> because in ubuntu there is no separate password for root,
> i access the root user using the password which is given by me at the time of installing.
> 
> But today i can't login as root user.
> I tried to go to  root by  using "sudo"  and  "su"  command and give the password which is the  password of installation  time,  it doesn't login as root.
> 
> I hope our LUG will give solution for this and advance thanks

Well, good that you couldn't login as root. Because, at least then you 
will find an alternate way of doing things which need administrator 
permissions. Logging in as root is bad habbit.

Though there is a way to enable root user, am not going to speak about 
it as it may lead to you logging in as root :p

If you are in Ubuntu, then you can do things which otherwise need 
superuser permissions, by using the sudo command. When you use sudo, you 
don't change to root user, rather get superuser privileges for your user 
account, so that you can perform such tasks.

References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>	<b40308c60612031925w24305b75o9bbfad126129e00a@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612031941s21d6e6eex22749bbfbee74cfa@mail.gmail.com>	<5f67d8bb0612032249u67c9e4e3k72b3786c813fc700@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>	<4573CC39.5010807@gmail.com>	<807C365D-1969-4F79-943F-2D26C7737786@thenilgiris.com>	<70106e0b0612041907w688d47f7nfa257ab721ea212@mail.gmail.com>	<6593151E-B43D-4DF7-8B9E-8F8526D8DD02@thenilgiris.com>	<4574F734.7060406@symonds.net>	<93F28444-6DA7-4180-ADF2-A16E8D28325C@thenilgiris.com>	<4574FF83.6090902@symonds.net>
	<CA841075-6198-4152-A8C1-40FCE42027DE@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <4575174D.7080008@symonds.net>

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:

> <quote>
> 
> Swapping live and neutral wires. In many countries this is not regarded
> as an error and it is perfectly feasible to design appliances such that
> they will be safe (e.g. by using double pole switches and protection
> devices) under this condition. However if appliances are intended for
> use only in countries that take care to avoid live/neutral swaps then
> they may have only a single pole switch which on live-neutral reversal
> will end up in the neutral wire, leaving portions of the device live at
> all times. This does not pose immediate danger but increases the risk of
> shock if there is another fault or if someone tries to work on the
> appliance without disconnecting it. For example if live and neutral have
> been swapped in lamps, the shell of the lamp base will be connected to
> the line, greatly increasing the risk of shock when changing light bulbs.
> 
> </quote>

This is given with respect to the use of a switch only. Most (all) of
the electric devices that have switches keep the switch control on the
so called live/phase line. Reversing the terminals may lead the live
wire to by-pass the switch which could cause shocks when you come into
contact with any of those wires. But this is more an usability issue.
The behavior of the device (functionality) will not change when you
reverse the terminals.

Praveen.

	<6593151E-B43D-4DF7-8B9E-8F8526D8DD02@thenilgiris.com>
	<4574F734.7060406@symonds.net>
	<93F28444-6DA7-4180-ADF2-A16E8D28325C@thenilgiris.com>
	<4574FF83.6090902@symonds.net>
	<CA841075-6198-4152-A8C1-40FCE42027DE@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612042303t17e69a4eve34d9b9d2e116039@mail.gmail.com>

On 05/12/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
> so what does this mean:
>
> <quote>
>
> Swapping live and neutral wires. In many countries this is not
> regarded as an error and it is perfectly feasible to design
> appliances such that they will be safe (e.g. by using double pole
> switches and protection devices) under this condition. However if
> appliances are intended for use only in countries that take care to
> avoid live/neutral swaps then they may have only a single pole switch
> which on live-neutral reversal will end up in the neutral wire,
> leaving portions of the device live at all times. This does not pose
> immediate danger but increases the risk of shock if there is another
> fault or if someone tries to work on the appliance without
> disconnecting it. For example if live and neutral have been swapped
> in lamps, the shell of the lamp base will be connected to the line,
> greatly increasing the risk of shock when changing light bulbs.
>
> </quote>

Well, this is exactly what many people have been saying in this thread
- that swapping phase and neutral pins is harmless in most cases.
Quoting Mano:

"Usually the phase is connected through the switch and the neutral
directly to the device. SO when the switch is OFF there is no power
supply to the device. When it is done otherwise, the phase is
connected directly with the device and even when the switch is OFF
there is power in the device"

In the specific case of light bulbs, the ones you see in India are of
the bayonet cap variety which doesn't use the shell of the lamp base
as the neutral pole - it has two separate poles at the bottom and a
plane of symmetry too.

I imagine double-pole switches are ones that opens both the phase and
the neutral side when in OFF position, so yes, they do mitigate
whatever shock situations that may present themselves when the
polarity is reversed.

Binand

From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Tue Dec  5 12:38:14 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Tue Dec  5 12:42:35 2006
Subject: [OT]Re: [Ilugc] Linksys WRT54GS power problems
In-Reply-To: <CA841075-6198-4152-A8C1-40FCE42027DE@thenilgiris.com>
References: <c293dd340612030022l44087061y14305960323dcd95@mail.gmail.com>	<b40308c60612031925w24305b75o9bbfad126129e00a@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612031941s21d6e6eex22749bbfbee74cfa@mail.gmail.com>	<5f67d8bb0612032249u67c9e4e3k72b3786c813fc700@mail.gmail.com>	<70106e0b0612032307h54cf28e1g32faed29f160f39b@mail.gmail.com>	<4573CC39.5010807@gmail.com>	<807C365D-1969-4F79-943F-2D26C7737786@thenilgiris.com>	<70106e0b0612041907w688d47f7nfa257ab721ea212@mail.gmail.com>	<6593151E-B43D-4DF7-8B9E-8F8526D8DD02@thenilgiris.com>	<4574F734.7060406@symonds.net>	<93F28444-6DA7-4180-ADF2-A16E8D28325C@thenilgiris.com>	<4574FF83.6090902@symonds.net>
	<CA841075-6198-4152-A8C1-40FCE42027DE@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <45751ADE.7070508@gmail.com>

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
> <quote>
> 
> Swapping live and neutral wires. In many countries this is not regarded 
> as an error and it is perfectly feasible to design appliances such that 
> they will be safe (e.g. by using double pole switches and protection 
> devices) under this condition. However if appliances are intended for 
> use only in countries that take care to avoid live/neutral swaps then 
> they may have only a single pole switch which on live-neutral reversal 
> will end up in the neutral wire, leaving portions of the device live at 
> all times. This does not pose immediate danger but increases the risk of 
> shock if there is another fault or if someone tries to work on the 
> appliance without disconnecting it. For example if live and neutral have 
> been swapped in lamps, the shell of the lamp base will be connected to 
> the line, greatly increasing the risk of shock when changing light bulbs.
> 
> </quote>

When you check out an US type power pin, which is followed in many other 
wester countries and Australia as well, the phase and neutral pins are 
not identical. The neutral pin is wider and easily identifiable. And 
also, you can not put it into the socket the other way. But, check the 
same with the Indian type, we have it identical round pins for both 
phase and neutral (and a bigger pin for Earth/ground). Thus, we never 
mind about which is phase and which is neutral and we most probably end 
up putting it in the wrong way. But, as this does not hinder the working 
of the instrument (provider it runs on single phase AC power supply), 
there is no issue. Even when we face a shock, we rather crib on the bad 
earth connections and wiring done by the electricians rather than 
getting into any detail of the actual cause, especially when the pins 
are in the other way into the socket.

-- 
With Regards

Parthan (TechnoFreak)

000 [Blog]http://technofreakatchennai.wordpress.com

The following statements that you have made has no connections with
cross-wiring. The reason for them are either insulation burst (in case
of geyser and stoves) or improper earthing.

<quote who="kg">
try plugging in an immersion heater or stove with the pins reversed and
see what happens
...

you will get a shock - also from other electrical appliances that are
cross wired - i dont know the theory behind, but i have got shocks
...

i have got shocks from fridges, microwave ovens and ordinary stoves -
when cross-wired, tester will glow when touching a metal part. Again, I
dont know the theory - but i have felt the pain
</quote>

From eamitdey at yahoo.com  Tue Dec  5 12:57:55 2006
From: eamitdey at yahoo.com (Amit Dey)
Date: Tue Dec  5 12:58:06 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Executing shell command in c program
Message-ID: <20061205072755.55513.qmail@web36801.mail.mud.yahoo.com>

I shell command can be executed thru c in this way
  system("pwd");
   
  Now this displays the output eg /usr/bin in the terminal window
   
  Is there anyway in which this output can be stored in a variable in the C program itself.
   

 
---------------------------------
Check out the all-new Yahoo! Mail beta - Fire up a more powerful email and get things done faster.
From binand at gmail.com  Tue Dec  5 13:02:06 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Tue Dec  5 13:02:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Executing shell command in c program
In-Reply-To: <20061205072755.55513.qmail@web36801.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061205072755.55513.qmail@web36801.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612042332u7a29ae05y102cd1a9d9bc85e2@mail.gmail.com>

On 05/12/06, Amit Dey <eamitdey@yahoo.com> wrote:
> I shell command can be executed thru c in this way
>   system("pwd");
>
>   Now this displays the output eg /usr/bin in the terminal window
>
>   Is there anyway in which this output can be stored in a variable in the C program itself.

No, C doesn't have the perl feature of $output = `somecommand`; You
need to use the popen() library function and parse through the output.

On the other hand, most simple commands can be easily emulated in C -
in this case, you have getcwd().

Binand
From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Tue Dec  5 13:12:01 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)

From niraj at efyindia.com  Tue Dec  5 13:13:48 2006
From: niraj at efyindia.com (Niraj Sahay)
Date: Tue Dec  5 13:13:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Share Your views with LINUX For You
Message-ID: <45752334.9020506@efyindia.com>

Hello All,

Greetings from the LINUX For You magazine team!

As you all know, we run a section called 'Opinions' in LFY where we pose 
a question to the community and industry and publish the responses 
(selected by our technical editors) in the magazine. Thanks to all those 
who responded to the last month's question. The best among the responses 
received have been published in the December 2006  issue of LFY.

The forthcoming issue of LFY would carry a story on the following:

Is the war really against Microsoft?

The article would focus on whether OSS world is actually fighting 
against proprietary software at an ideological level. Or is it that it 
remains a battle against Microsoft? We would like to focus at the 
various levels on which this antagonism between the open source 
evangelists and believers on proprietary software shapes up. Is the 
discontentment against Microsoft only to the extent of patent issues? Or 
that Microsoft is just a mere player, while the FOSS community is 
fighting at the much higher level of psychology...

We value your suggestions and comments. So, any idea you would like to 
share with us is most welcome.

Please write to us at sujata.banerjee@efyindia.com with a CC to 
atul@efyindia.com, before 10th November,2006.

The best responses would be published in the Jan 2007 issue of LFY.

Looking forward to your responses.

Thanks,

Sujata Banerjee, Editorial Coordinator, LFY
Atul Goel, Asst. Associate Editor, LFY

points here are perfectly circular).

Message-ID: <a8f990120612050046o25fcca13hb406b3ce6b42fe4@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/5/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>
> Hey hey hey... hang on... the phase and neutral pins are identical all
> over the world (at least, the civilized world).


  Definitely not in the U.S. and Japan:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_AC_power_plugs_and_sockets#Type_A_.28North_American.2FJapanese_2-pin.29

The wider pin is neutral, and the 2-pin plug cannot be physically inserted
reversed in such a socket. This helps prevent shock hazards on 'hot chassis'
appliances, including TVs, microwaves, etc.

Note that the design is carried over into the 3-pin grounded socket as well,
to prevent 2-pin plugs from being inserted reversed.

(And yes, I am an EE, among other things).

-Siva

> > so called live/phase line. Reversing the terminals may lead the live
> > wire to by-pass the switch which could cause shocks when you come into

This is not to reply anybody in particular, but apart from going way
OT, we have kinda lost focus on the first issue. We have discussed
quite a bit on Phase Neutral wiring that can cause shocks in
*alternating current* applications. But the original problem initiated
with phase-neutral wiring for a AC/DC converter.

From mailzico at gmail.com  Wed Dec  6 10:16:50 2006
From: mailzico at gmail.com (Zico)
Date: Wed Dec  6 10:16:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re:could't access the root account
In-Reply-To: <e24507ef0612052038o12075e41vc6a607d0c89eaef@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0612042239t5c5ff16ei51cbcd34caabf61c@mail.gmail.com>
	<457518D3.8060309@gmail.com>
	<A8BDBD71-C98F-4780-AA44-C61D5450EA88@thenilgiris.com>
	<e24507ef0612052038o12075e41vc6a607d0c89eaef@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <69621d830612052046k71f43721qfd43f63ef8374587@mail.gmail.com>

Ok, guys, there is a problem in ubuntu. And that is, the "shadow password"
is not enable there as default. So, what you need to do, is:

when the boot loader comes, select

"Ubuntu kernel---............."

press "e"

then select "kernel...."

press "e"

write "linux single" last line of "kernel.......>"

then, the login shell of root will come and change the "actual" password
from there...

And go for next process as other guys told....

Happy computing!

Zico

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Wed Dec  6 10:55:00 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Wed Dec  6 10:45:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Spl Meet on this Week end
In-Reply-To: <adc51dea0612051228i2b9fda7do2eca626815c6f453@mail.gmail.com>

On Tue, 5 Dec 2006, Aanjhan R wrote:

> > On this week end, Mr Uma Shankar, Chief ELCOT, wants to interact
> > with us, to share the ELCOT's present developments, immediate and
> > future plans on FOSS.
> 
> Can someone elaborate on the happenings??

6 or 7 members attended this meet. The meet started around 5:45PM.

By mid of Dec, ELCOT is planning to ship nearly 3K PCs to all
panchayat offices in TN. PCs are shipped with only Suse Distro (as
against the initial Dual Boot decision). If anybody insist on M$, to
compensate the cost, the DVD Writer and 17"inch LCD will be removed
and Suse + M$ + 15" CRT will be provided.

ELCOT responsibility is train the official on the Linux Env. ELCOT is
looking for few personals(M/F) with good looking, voice and nice
teaching skills in Tamil Language to prepare the video lectures.
Anybody interested, Plz join in the next LUG meet.

The Training session will be done thru Video lectures and Volunteers
are needed to clear the doubts raised during that time. Nearly 100
volunteers are needed to support the training programs at different
locations in TN. (Plz fwd this message to other TN LUGs. So that ELCOT
can get more LOCAL Volunteers).

Another good news is, due to the ELCOT tender terms, many laptop and
PC manufactures and distributors are started dev the Linux Drivers (I
hope, they will release it in GPL). For example, Xerox came to tender
only after developing the CUPS PPT files (Someone took a copy of that
PPT file in USB Stick. Plz share in LUG).

Bye :)
--
Bharathi S

On 12/5/06, Parthan <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> When you check out an US type power pin, which is followed in many other
> wester countries and Australia as well, the phase and neutral pins are
> not identical. The neutral pin is wider and easily identifiable. And
> also, you can not put it into the socket the other way. But, check the
> same with the Indian type, we have it identical round pins for both
> phase and neutral (and a bigger pin for Earth/ground). Thus, we never
> mind about which is phase and which is neutral and we most probably end
> up putting it in the wrong way. But, as this does not hinder the working
> of the instrument (provider it runs on single phase AC power supply),
> there is no issue. Even when we face a shock, we rather crib on the bad
> earth connections and wiring done by the electricians rather than
> getting into any detail of the actual cause, especially when the pins
> are in the other way into the socket.
>

Sometimes the electricians ARE at fault. Just as we users do not bother
about phase and neutral, some electricians dont do too! When in college I
watched my friend getting a nasty shock trying to clean a bulb holder with
the switch off.  As he was getting on the chair I asked him what if the
phase and neutral are wrongly wired....  he said "dont be silly... this is
an engineering college.... " :-)

regds,
mano
-- 
War is not about who's right..... its about who's left!

From sivaramsk at midascomm.com  Wed Dec  6 14:32:31 2006
From: sivaramsk at midascomm.com (Sivaram)
Date: Wed Dec  6 14:40:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Help with Fluxbox.
In-Reply-To: <457505B4.6020306@gopalarathnam.com>
References: <4574F2D8.30108@midascomm.com>	<20061205051106.GB31745@lakshmi.susmita.org>
	<45750049.4060704@midascomm.com>
	<457505B4.6020306@gopalarathnam.com>
Message-ID: <45768727.5040104@midascomm.com>


Hi Gopal,
> Just create a file named ".xsession" in your home directory with 
> execute permissions and add the line "exec /path/to/yourwm".
>
> In GDM, choose the system default or something equivalent.  It'll run 
> "$HOME/.xsession".
>
Thanks. This method worked.

regards,
siva.
From binand at gmail.com  Wed Dec  6 14:59:40 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)

Agenda:

Talk 1 : Intro to RRDTool - By Bharathi

RRDTool used for logging and graphing the Time-series data. Talk
covers the basic command sets, collection, archiving and graphing of
data.

The Govt. of TN is making plans to finalise a new encoding for Tamil,
called TUNE.  Though the intent is good, TUNE may end up introducing
more problems rather than solving any of the issues. Ramanraj will 
discuss about this issues.

From binand at gmail.com  Wed Dec  6 15:42:10 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Wed Dec  6 15:42:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] High Availability
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0612061534070.31811-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
References: <d2a92d610612060129if49e155oe13af79ccb071204@mail.gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0612061534070.31811-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612060212p1883fadja8240cc44ae80907@mail.gmail.com>

On 06/12/06, Bharathi Subramanian <sbharathi@midascomm.com> wrote:
> What about the Mail contents? How do I make it available in the
> standby machine?

Heh. There you enter a major problem with most HA configurations. :)

At the network level, you can load balance via MX records, and for
POP/IMAP etc., you can have keepalived+rsync to provide for a hot
standby. But for the mail store itself, you will need to have some
sort of network filesystem (NFS or CIFS, let us say), but by doing
that you only transfer your single point of failure from the
mailserver to the fileserver. Redhat's GFS does try to provide highly
available file store, but it looks to me rather expensive and is a
bitch to build/maintain.

Binand

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Wed Dec  6 16:22:21 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Wed Dec  6 16:22:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] High Availability
In-Reply-To: <20061206093627.GA19046@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0612061100440.29756-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
	<20061206093627.GA19046@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <20061206105221.GA1977@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Wed, Dec 06, 2006 at 03:06:27PM +0530, Girish Venkatachalam wrote:
> On Wed, Dec 06, 2006 at 11:30:33AM +0530, Bharathi Subramanian wrote:
> > Hi,
> > 
> > Anybody having experience in implementing the High Availability
> > stuffs, Plz help me to find the good method to achieve the hot-standby
> > model for mail server. Presently I am going thru the Linux-HA Projects
> > like Heartbeat and DRBD. Any other pointers/links are welcome.
> 
> Perhaps you have not considered that putting OpenBSD carp+pfsync at the perimeter can give you higher "availability" than any other method?

Another possibility is live migration with xen.

I am told you can achieve live migration within 300 milliseconds(gasp).

I tend to think that high availability is best ensured by either OS level or layer 2 level stuff.

Higher layers make things more difficult, expensive, complex.

However you may not have a choice as you have to consider other factors.

But ceteris paribus I would go with the above two.

Best,
Girish

Friends.

Today, i added some NAS drives to a RH server.
In the server already there are more partitions.
They all are Primary partitions only (code 83)

Today, when i am adding the NAS device,
i tend to create it as a primary partition.
But when a windowz guy saw that, he told,

"Creating more primary partitions is an bad.
there should be only one primary partition.
then only the MBR will live safely
and the addition and deletion of partitions in the future
will be easy and safe.

Create extended partition and make logical partitions there.
this is very good".

Is it true?

Please explain me on What is primary, extended, logical partitions?
and the number of primary partitions can be created.

Thanks,
T.Shrinivasan.

Hey,

	I am no guru in this regard.

	But still I will throw in my mite.

	You can have upto 4 primary partitions on an x86 machine for a given hard disk.

	Out of this exactly one of them is active/bootable.

	I shall leave the good/bad/subjective stuff out.

	Hope this helps.

Best,
Girish

Sorry I lost your mail. Deleted mindlessly. :)

You need two OpenBSD machines for carp to work. It is the easiest high availability setup on earth.

Just proxy arp + carp magic.

Perhaps Raja can throw more light on this.

I am yet to try it out but people often criticize Ryan McBride for making things so simple that most sys admins don't feel a sense of accomplishment. :)

People like to solve hard problems right?

From solar345 at gmail.com  Wed Dec  6 18:00:07 2006
From: solar345 at gmail.com (Antano Solar)
Date: Wed Dec  6 18:00:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] adding multimedia on debian etch testing
In-Reply-To: <dd680c2b0612060347w4d8bc01ajc5c5adfa81f65db2@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0612060347w4d8bc01ajc5c5adfa81f65db2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <b2600ec40612060430i73b692d7r452332aec296d185@mail.gmail.com>

most probably the scenario is that the libraries in your dvd's are
outdated compared to the multimedia repository you have added.

probably a apt-get dist-upgrade should help

or ty manually downloading the dependencies mentioned from
packages.debian.org make sure you download only the  testing packages.

then dpkg -i packagename

things must work fine this way  on your comp

*Note : If you want to distribute the dvds , then the best thing to do
is , mount your dvd
and then download the latest dvd jigdo's from the website ,
and run jigdo-lite.

This way you will get the latest dvd iso's but you wil end up
downloading only the difference.

Hope it helps and about apt-get update i dont know why it shows so
many list , but it happens in my computer too and i guess its normal
From senthils at au-kbc.org  Wed Dec  6 18:12:22 2006
From: senthils at au-kbc.org (S. Senthil Anand)
Date: Wed Dec  6 18:12:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] adding multimedia on debian etch testing
In-Reply-To: <dd680c2b0612060347w4d8bc01ajc5c5adfa81f65db2@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0612060347w4d8bc01ajc5c5adfa81f65db2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4576BAAE.70304@au-kbc.org>

Shrinivasan T wrote:
> What is DiffIndex?
>
> It should show only four entries as 3 DVd + one website.
>
> why it is showing so many things?
>
> Please guide me to solve this problem and install all the multimedia 
> hacks.
>
> Thanks.
> T.Shrinivasan.
>
Hi,

Your DVDs have old packages. The testing branch has been updated since 
9th October. If you want to use debian-multimedia.org, you have to have 
the main debian repository from an official Debian mirror.

If you look at the logs, apt-get is ignoring the paths for the GPG key, 
the release file and other information in the 3 DVDs. All the time it is 
searching in the 3 DVDs only. This is perfectly normal.

Debian now uses diff of the package index to update the local package 
information. For the first time it will download the whole index and 
from the next apt-get update, it will load the index as a series of diff 
files for each passing day.

mplayer is now in Debian main. I am not sure if it has propagated to 
testing yet. The version in main might also be missing support for some 
formats.

I would also suggest that you use 'etch' rather than 'testing' as the 
release name, as etch will released soon.

Regards,
Senthil

Hi,

I personally prefer source code and other technical papers to learn about operating systems than books.

ps(1) output is very instructive in this regard.

Check out the two.

http://girish1729.googlepages.com/linuxps.pdf

http://girish1729.googlepages.com/obsd-ps.pdf

The linux entry is longer but...

Many people often ask me, "So why should I look beyond linux?"

What is the purpose of working with different OSes? Isn't everything just POSIX or some clone of UNIX?

If so then you can get a POSIX compliant environment on Windoze with Cygwin but do you like it? :)

Point to ponder.

Good nite.

ttfn,
Girish

Subject: [Ilugc] explain on partitions
In-Reply-To: <dd680c2b0612060328n763e0e5as305ddd35ffaf6de9@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0612060328n763e0e5as305ddd35ffaf6de9@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4577A6D6.6050902@gmx.net>

Shrinivasan T wrote:
> Today, i added some NAS drives to a RH server. In the server already
> there are more partitions. They all are Primary partitions only (code
> 83)
> 
> Today, when i am adding the NAS device, i tend to create it as a
> primary partition. But when a windowz guy saw that, he told,

NAS or SAN?

> "Creating more primary partitions is an bad. there should be only one
> primary partition. then only the MBR will live safely and the
> addition and deletion of partitions in the future will be easy and
> safe.
> 
> Create extended partition and make logical partitions there. this is
> very good".

Hmm. I dont see a reasoning behind it. maybe it is easier for data
recovery if you lose your MBR. When using extended partitions., your
parition information (but for the entire extended partition) is stored
all over the drive as a linked list. However., does not seem like a
great advantage though :-S Maybe i'm wrong.

From solar345 at gmail.com  Thu Dec  7 15:11:28 2006
From: solar345 at gmail.com (Antano Solar)
Date: Thu Dec  7 15:11:41 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] explain on partitions
In-Reply-To: <4577A6D6.6050902@gmx.net>
References: <dd680c2b0612060328n763e0e5as305ddd35ffaf6de9@mail.gmail.com>
	<4577A6D6.6050902@gmx.net>
Message-ID: <b2600ec40612070141u365d6071y71266ec017508091@mail.gmail.com>

The only reason i have heard , for having extended and logical
partitions is because there cant be more than 4 primary partitions.

Resizing and even deleting and adding partitions is more convenient
with just primary partitions.

When it comes to data recovery again , primary partitions are searched
as single partitions , but with logical partitions , the collection
under an extended partition is searched as a single partition.

Haven't read or heard anything more about partitons , it would be nice
someone else could add :)

And correct me if I am wrong , the MBR is always on the first
partition , regardless of whether you create primary or extended
partitons , its usage and method of accesing is always the same.
From binand at gmail.com  Thu Dec  7 15:14:11 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Thu Dec  7 15:14:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] explain on partitions
In-Reply-To: <b2600ec40612070141u365d6071y71266ec017508091@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0612060328n763e0e5as305ddd35ffaf6de9@mail.gmail.com>
	<4577A6D6.6050902@gmx.net>
	<b2600ec40612070141u365d6071y71266ec017508091@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612070144r39b388ccw6177d5b9ef326633@mail.gmail.com>

On 07/12/06, Antano Solar <solar345@gmail.com> wrote:
> The only reason i have heard , for having extended and logical
> partitions is because there cant be more than 4 primary partitions.

The reason for this is that the 512-byte first sector of the HDD (the
MBR) is divided as 448-byte boot loader code followed by a 64-byte
partition table. Since each partition table entry requires 16 bytes,
you are limited to 4 such entries.

Binand

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Dec  7 17:11:37 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Dec  7 17:11:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] explain on partitions
In-Reply-To: <e597802d0612070218p5ce9e3e5ycd3851ae0a3ee559@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dd680c2b0612060328n763e0e5as305ddd35ffaf6de9@mail.gmail.com>
	<4577A6D6.6050902@gmx.net>
	<b2600ec40612070141u365d6071y71266ec017508091@mail.gmail.com>
	<e597802d0612070218p5ce9e3e5ycd3851ae0a3ee559@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20061207114137.GA14671@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Dec 07, 2006 at 03:48:51PM +0530, Krishna P wrote:
> On 12/7/06, Antano Solar <solar345@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> >
> >And correct me if I am wrong , the MBR is always on the first
> >partition , regardless of whether you create primary or extended
> >
> 
> MBR lies in  first sector of the Hard disk not on the first partition.

MBR consists of IPL(Initial Program Load code) for 448 bytes and a 64 Byte partition table in that order in the first track of the hard disk. Every single OS partition on hard disk starts from the second track of the disk... usually.

If you want to back up or zero your MBR dd serves nicely.

#dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/hda bs=512 count=1
#dd if=/dev/hda of=/mbr  bs=512 count=1

So be careful with reinstalls on old hard disks. You are better off just wiping out the MBR with the above command.

regards,
Girish

From solar345 at gmail.com  Thu Dec  7 21:21:17 2006
From: solar345 at gmail.com (Antano Solar)
Date: Thu Dec  7 21:21:54 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] explain on partitions
In-Reply-To: <20061207114137.GA14671@lakshmi.susmita.org>
References: <dd680c2b0612060328n763e0e5as305ddd35ffaf6de9@mail.gmail.com>
	<4577A6D6.6050902@gmx.net>
	<b2600ec40612070141u365d6071y71266ec017508091@mail.gmail.com>
	<e597802d0612070218p5ce9e3e5ycd3851ae0a3ee559@mail.gmail.com>
	<20061207114137.GA14671@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <b2600ec40612070751t27f4411dkf665b8df5a9e480e@mail.gmail.com>

>
>
> MBR consists of IPL(Initial Program Load code) for 448 bytes and a 64 Byte
> partition table in that order in the first track of the hard disk. Every
> single OS partition on hard disk starts from the second track of the disk...
> usually.
>
> If you want to back up or zero your MBR dd serves nicely.
>
> #dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/hda bs=512 count=1
> #dd if=/dev/hda of=/mbr  bs=512 count=1
>
> So be careful with reinstalls on old hard disks. You are better off just
> wiping out the MBR with the above command.
>
> regards,
> Girish
>
> So shrinivasan you can tell your windows frined that what he said has no
truth in it :)
From nagappan at gmail.com  Thu Dec  7 23:21:33 2006
From: nagappan at gmail.com (Nagappan A)
Date: Thu Dec  7 23:22:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux Desktop Testing Project (LDTP) 0.7.0 released !
Message-ID: <9d0602eb0612070951u17272f9ek4479855383306803@mail.gmail.com>

We are proud to announce the release of LDTP 0.7.0. This release features
number of important breakthroughs in LDTP as well as in the field of Test
Automation. This release note covers a brief introduction on LDTP followed
by the list of new features and major bug fixes which makes this new version
of LDTP the best of the breed. Useful references have been included at the
end of this article for those who wish to hack / use LDTP.

About LDTP
==========

Linux Desktop Testing Project is aimed at producing high quality test
automation framework (C/Python) and cutting-edge tools that can be used to
test Linux Desktop and improve it. It uses the Accessibility libraries to
poke through the application's user interface. The framework also has tools
to record test-cases based on user events in the interface of the
application which is under testing. We strive to help in building a quality
desktop.

Whats new in this release...
====================
+ Major performance enhancement
    In this release major contribution from Rodney Dawes  <dobey@novell.com>.
Valgrinded LDTP engine and fixed lot of memory leaks in LDTP and improved
the performance.

+ Major rewritten of LDTP Error structure, LDTP Command structure.

+ Now LDTP uses python logging module.

+ Bug fixes
    This version includes loads of bug fixes to address important issues
like memory leak, API functionality, accessibility compatible issues etc.,
For a detailed list please refer to release notes section of our project
site hosted in http://ldtp.freedesktop.org. Thanks to all the developers for
their contribution and Rodney Dawes (dobey) especially.

Download source tarball -
http://download.freedesktop.org/ldtp/0.x/0.7.x/ldtp-0.7.0.tar.gz

LDTP news
=========

* Accessibility test suite by Rodney Dawes (dobey) -
http://webcvs.freedesktop.org/ldtp/a11y-test-suite/
* LDTP Presentation in FOSS.IN/2006 by Prashanth Mohan, Bangalore, India

LDTP Recording demo
=============

Record / Playback of scripts -
http://people.freedesktop.org/~nagappan/ldtpguidemo.html

References
==========

For detailed information on LDTP framework and latest updates visit
http://ldtp.freedesktop.org

For information on various APIs in LDTP including those added for this
release can be got from http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/user-doc/index.html

To subscribe to LDTP mailing lists, visit
http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/wiki/Mailing_20list

IRC Channel - #ldtp on irc.freenode.net

For suggestions to improve this newsletter, please write to
jpremkumar@novell.com


-- 
Linux Desktop Testing Project - http://ldtp.freedesktop.org
http://nagappanal.blogspot.com

On 12/7/06, Antano Solar <solar345@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> > So shrinivasan you can tell your windows frined that what he said has no
> truth in it :)
>

During installation Windows tries to occupy the entire disk. If you want
more than one partition it will create all the extra partitions as extended.
I think the intention is to make installation of another OS difficult and
can hopefully discourage the less adventurous.

Probably the OP's friend was brought up in a purely MS env and might be
thinking if it is the MS way it should be the right way :-)

regds,
mano
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Dec  8 09:22:13 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Dec  8 09:22:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Where is Kernel parameter file located
In-Reply-To: <96236.2348.qm@web36712.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061208035213.68316.qmail@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

--- Anandh G <anandhg02@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Wher is the kernel parameter file located in linux.

Paremeter file? What does it do?

> I
> found the /etc/sysconfig/sysctl.conf file, but there
> are no entries in that file by default. 

You can add any entries you want and invoke it with
sysctl.

> If I issue sysctl -a command, I am getting more than
> 200 parameters, which file holds all these entries. 

These are read at run-time dynamically from the
kernel. The entries can also be viewed from /proc/sys.
/proc is not a physical filesystem. All data read is
from the kernel at run-time.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Fri Dec  8 10:11:40 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Fri Dec  8 10:02:06 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Where is Kernel parameter file located
In-Reply-To: <96236.2348.qm@web36712.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0612081003370.12150-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

On Fri, 8 Dec 2006, Anandh G wrote:

> Wher is the kernel parameter file located in linux. 

To the know the list of Kernel Params, look into this file 
/usr/src/linux-XYZ/Documentation/kernel-parameters.txt

To check the current params to the kernel, look into the
boot-loader config file (like menu.lst or lilo.conf).

Bye :)
-- 
Bharathi S

The best way is to ask the recipients if anyone has stored the

certain to find the full archive. Web scraping might not work, mainly
due to the ad-infestation in Yahoo.

From binand at gmail.com  Fri Dec  8 21:01:40 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Dec  8 21:01:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Where is Kernel parameter file located
In-Reply-To: <639848.70431.qm@web36702.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <20061208035213.68316.qmail@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>
	<639848.70431.qm@web36702.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612080731p4b0b7209g87628b68568caa03@mail.gmail.com>

On 08/12/06, Anandh G <anandhg02@yahoo.com> wrote:
> I want to know the same, is the kernel parameter is
> within the kernel or is it stored in a file and is
> read while the system boots.

Most of them are compile-time hardcoded defaults; but if you want to
change anything, you can reconfigure a running kernel via echo
something > /proc/sys/somewhere (which is what happens when you do a
sysctl -p, and is also part of your system init scripts).

Binand
