From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Thu Dec 21 18:36:13 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Thu Dec 21 18:36:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] : queries about Cryptography
In-Reply-To: <65554.67688.qm@web36814.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <65554.67688.qm@web36814.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061221130613.GA7815@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Thu, Dec 21, 2006 at 03:53:37AM -0800, Amit Dey wrote:
> OK Guys....Please dont hate me for doing this.
> 
> I know this mailing list is for linux related stuff. But I need to know if there exist any mailing list and/or IRC channels for cryptography related stuff. I have no one else to ask and i thought maybe some of u guys may have done some crypto work.

There must be crypto related mailing lists and IRC channels I am sure but I have only been listening to OpenSSH, OpenSSL and OpenBSD mailing lists. But these are really advanced and not suited for crypto beginners.

Pick up a copy of Applied Cryptography by Bruce Schneier and read it. He has written it in an entertaining manner.


Another good book is Introduction to cryptography or some such title by William H Stallings.

Frankly it took me at least 4 months to get a grasp of crypto and nearly a year to become comfortable with it. It is both broad and deep.

I did start with browsing the Internet. 

Hope this answers your question. You are welcome to get in touch with me personally should you have further questions.

Best of luck!

regards,
Girish

days (17h 48m 50s) ago

you can discuss anything in #anything 
good luck.


> > 
> > I know this mailing list is for linux related stuff. But I need to know if there exist any mailing list and/or IRC channels for cryptography related stuff. I have no one else to ask and i thought maybe some of u guys may have done some crypto work.
> 
> There must be crypto related mailing lists and IRC channels I am sure but I have only been listening to OpenSSH, OpenSSL and OpenBSD mailing lists. But these are really advanced and not suited for crypto beginners.
> 
> Pick up a copy of Applied Cryptography by Bruce Schneier and read it. He has written it in an entertaining manner.
> 
> 
> Another good book is Introduction to cryptography or some such title by William H Stallings.
> 
> Frankly it took me at least 4 months to get a grasp of crypto and nearly a year to become comfortable with it. It is both broad and deep.
> 
> I did start with browsing the Internet. 
> 
> Hope this answers your question. You are welcome to get in touch with me personally should you have further questions.
> 
> Best of luck!
> 
> regards,
> Girish
> _______________________________________________
> To unsubscribe, email ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in with 
> "unsubscribe <password> <address>"
> in the subject or body of the message.  
> http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc

hi!

On 12/21/06, Bharathi Subramanian <sbharathi@midascomm.com> wrote:
>
> Hi All,
>
> Is it possible to do some simple arithmetic in gnuplot during the
> plotting? For example, in the following cmd, I want to multiply the
> 5th col by 100 before plotting.
>
> plot "Foo" using 4:5 title 'Foo' with lines


http://www.gnuplot.info/docs/gnuplot.html#Functions

When it can do Bessels functions.. This should be pooh for it.. It's
possible !!

plot "Foo" using 4:(100*$5) title "Foo" with lines

bye !

ganesh

error can not connect mysql server thro mysql.sock in

the mysql server is properly running

From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Thu Dec 21 23:53:12 2006

kumar esan wrote:
> hi friends
> 
> i working with suse 10.0
> 
> i got one error message while entering to mysql prompt
> 
> the error msg like this
> error can not connect mysql server thro mysql.sock in
> var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock (111)
> 
> the mysql server is properly running
> /etc/init.d mysql started successfully
> tell me solution
> 

Probably the socket is created under /tmp.
Try mysql -S /tmp/mysql.sock.

Gopalarathnam Venkatesan

http://gopalarathnam.com/
From codeshepherd at gmail.com  Fri Dec 22 06:36:11 2006
From: codeshepherd at gmail.com (Deepan)
Date: Fri Dec 22 06:39:03 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] problem in mysql
In-Reply-To: <458AD110.6000200@gopalarathnam.com>
References: <dffb4c0b0612211018n1e3b6d34vb7886e93473b7fce@mail.gmail.com>
	<458AD110.6000200@gopalarathnam.com>
Message-ID: <1166749571.2727.29.camel@codeworld>

On Thu, 2006-12-21 at 23:53 +0530, Gopalarathnam Venkatesan wrote:
> kumar esan wrote:
> > hi friends
> > 
> > i working with suse 10.0
> > 
> > i got one error message while entering to mysql prompt
> > 
> > the error msg like this
> > error can not connect mysql server thro mysql.sock in
> > var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock (111)
> > 
> > the mysql server is properly running
> > /etc/init.d mysql started successfully


enable mysql logging. what contents do u have in my.cnf ? what interface
is mysql listening at ? you can find this from netstat output.  what do
u see in the log files ? 
the contents of my my.cnf  are 



 cat /etc/my.cnf
[mysqld]
datadir=/var/lib/mysql
socket=/var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock
set-variable = max_allowed_packet=16M
log=/tmp/mysqld.log
     
[mysql.server]
user=mysql
basedir=/var/lib
log=/tmp/mysqld.log

[safe_mysqld]
err-log=/var/log/mysqld.log
pid-file=/var/run/mysqld/mysqld.pid






> > tell me solution
> > 
> 
> Probably the socket is created under /tmp.
> Try mysql -S /tmp/mysql.sock.
>

>> http://yahoopops.sourceforge.net

How to install video card from command prompt.

From goda.abishek at gmail.com  Fri Dec 22 10:49:08 2006
From: goda.abishek at gmail.com (Ingeneur)
Date: Fri Dec 22 10:49:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] doubt
In-Reply-To: <47b442230612212111h29f80d9qdab7189b7bc938c7@mail.gmail.com>
References: <47b442230612212111h29f80d9qdab7189b7bc938c7@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <70106e0b0612212119k4e39b807u8302ea67355d47e6@mail.gmail.com>

> How to install video card from command prompt.
> I am using Red Hat Linux 9.

I think kudzu should have detected it on booting. Did you have this
card during install or did you add it recently? If you are having
problems getting an X11 display, try
X -configure
will create a /root/corg.conf.new and
X -config xorg.conf.new

If that worked, replace /etc/X11/xorg.conf with /root/xorg.conf.new

Btw, I don't know if it is xorg.conf or XF86config in RH9. But it
applies to both, i think.

PS:You might need to edit the mouse device section alone

-- 
Regards,

Abishek Goda
http://goda.abishek.googlepages.com

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Fri Dec 22 16:07:54 2006
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Fri Dec 22 16:09:08 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] USB resetting (was: Buying a portable external hard -
	Linux	compatibility)
In-Reply-To: <9a9bfc170612220226x3bd51b83qe28f954ba48e6bf5@mail.gmail.com>
References: <9a9bfc170612220226x3bd51b83qe28f954ba48e6bf5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <458BB582.7040202@frodo.hserus.net>

R.Ramkumar wrote:
> 
> The problem in my case is different (I think). The device mounts,
> everything works well... Once in a while, after a long time, it just
> stops for a minute and continues... I suspect that the drive gets
> heated up.. I am not hardware expert, but I guess those in the list
> could point at what the problem could be...
> 

Do you get any DMA errors on that thing?  A lot of those USB hard disks
are cheap old IDE / noname taiwanese types .. or its an older USB bus
and the data transfer for a large file / frequent disk reads etc
overloads the USB bus so there's a delay, sometimes.

R.Ramkumar wrote:
> 
> nope.. no fan :( i am thinking if I should run it without the
> aluminium casing... the richie street guy scared me off the idea
> saying the circuitry is too complex :) but i guess it should help

Anything over a simple ckt to demonstrate ohms law is probably too
complex for the guy. You can easily bolt on an external fan and I've
seen several casings that do come with fans [mercy electronics adyar
though, not ritchie street]

Al casing + no fan is not going to cool your hdd down very much.

mysql -u root -p

From ambuj.mbp at gmail.com  Fri Dec 22 18:59:08 2006
From: ambuj.mbp at gmail.com (Ambuj Thacker)
Date: Fri Dec 22 18:59:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: video card
Message-ID: <c021e3c90612220529o5d63b6dcoe0007baff0014221@mail.gmail.com>

>From command line kudzu can be used to find the new h/w connected to
conputer that is not detected while boot up.If you are still using the old
kernel then upgrade to new one.Its very easy to get the new kernel.Just get
the kernel image(its in /boot/vmlinuz<version>) from any linux box
having new kernel and dont forget the initrd image(/boot/initrd.img) :) (or
you can use mkinitrd command for that,but you will require the kernel source
:) ).Most likely the module for your video card will be there,if it is not
present then do mail the details of video card to LUG mailing list.

Ambuj
  :)

From anandsaha at gmail.com  Fri Dec 22 23:02:50 2006
From: anandsaha at gmail.com (Anand Saha)
Date: Fri Dec 22 23:03:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] dynamic charting / graphing
In-Reply-To: <5d8c3fec0612220639j75af9e98g7952b4f79339fecd@mail.gmail.com>

Message-ID: <154eca020612220932o42fa4c63m8fe26f276d13f9b6@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/22/06, anantha narasimhan <anantha.narasimhan@gmail.com> wrote:
> im trying to build a dynamic and interactive graph on a web page , data for
> which is constantly updated from the server side. which is the best
> tool/library that can programatically be used to generate graphs for
> rendering in web pages. i tried using plotkit, but it seems to be a bit
> sloppy. im also looking to show datatips when the mouse moves over the
> curve.

If you are ok with programming, you might try the GD library with php.
http://in.php.net/gd

that, with javascript, might help you show tooltips.

For reporting needs, I had once used Jasper, which is an opensource
reporting engine, connects to database and let's you generate reports
with images - on the fly, with images as well if needed.
http://jasperforge.org/sf/projects/jasperreports

saha
--
From km at mrna.tn.nic.in  Fri Dec 22 23:18:05 2006
From: km at mrna.tn.nic.in (km)
Date: Fri Dec 22 23:09:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] usb harddisk
In-Reply-To: <20061216051117.96145.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20061215210309.GA31772@mrna.tn.nic.in>
	<20061216051117.96145.qmail@web50206.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20061222174805.GA11786@mrna.tn.nic.in>

Hi all,

aah ! atlast ! i could make my usb external hdd work hotplugged! on an x86_64 RHEL 4.0

I had statically compiled 'sd_mod', 'scsi_mod' (as i have a pure scsi hardware), 'usbcore', 'usb-storage' and left 'st' and 'sg' to be dynamicially compiled into the kernel 2.6.18.3.
after that i could boot properly,  and then had to install sg_utils additionally  (since GLIBC < 2.4)
(if GLIBC >= 2.4 install sg3_utils package)
and then scanned the scsi interfaces with 'sg_scan -i'
then-onwards, when i plug in the usb hdd, udev automatically creates device file to access the external harddrive and i could mount and format it.
now 'lsusb' also shows the device :)

thank u for all ur inputs.
regards,
KM

------------------------------------------------------------------

Zico wrote:
> come one.. guys.. you should not call it "ancient"...
> i feel upset...
> even today.. when i am using debian...
> if i see Gnome of Red Hat 9.0 in any computer screen.. i felt like... "
> AAAAhhhhh.... i lost my beautiful girlfriend...."
But RH9 is ancient.

It was released on March 31st, 2003 and comes with zero support or 
updates now. No one knows how many security holes are in it now. Unless 
installing on an old system it wont work properly because it does not 
support newer hardware technologies.

If you miss the Bluecurve look under Debian install 
gtk2-engines-wonderland to get it.

Regards,
Senthil

References: <5d8c3fec0612220639j75af9e98g7952b4f79339fecd@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <a0c4f6270612221748p7e7aa1e9y367728ddf491b844@mail.gmail.com>

On 22/12/06, anantha narasimhan wrote:
> hey all,
>
> im trying to build a dynamic and interactive graph on a web page , data for
> which is constantly updated from the server side. which is the best
> tool/library that can programatically be used to generate graphs for
> rendering in web pages. i tried using plotkit, but it seems to be a bit
> sloppy. im also looking to show datatips when the mouse moves over the
> curve.

Since you have not mentioned the programming language you are using, I
would also mention Matplotlib for Python. It's excellent, and can be
used for non-interactive plotting as well.

http://matplotlib.sf.net

HTH

Kumar

Quoting Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com>:

> Come on. The Fedora Legacy project (and others too, some commercial)
> still support RH9. Remember that Redhat always had a big commercial
> customer base who were less inclined to upgrade to later versions (if
> I had my way, I'd still be running the rock-solid RH 7.3) - that has
> spun off several companies/organisations who offer support for these
> old versions.
> 
> http://www.fedoralegacy.org/
> http://www.progeny.com/
> etc...


These services may be suitable for people who already have a large investment in
RH9 but not for anyone else and they are also disappearing slowly.

I often have people new to Linux asking for RH9 and I always steer them away
from it. They seem to have heard about RH9 but are completely in the dark about
Fedora.

And FYI,
Fedora Legacy won't maintain support for FC4 and lower since Dec 12th.
The Progeny service also ended last year.

Regards,
Senthil

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Dec 24 12:40:05 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Dec 24 12:40:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Installing GNU/ Linux to USB Hard Drive
Message-ID: <417437.87682.qm@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

> Now I would like to have an OS installed on it 

Install any recent distribution on it.

> notebook and choose the USB as first boot device,
the 
> OS installed on USB
> HDD should boot.

For this to happen, you need to install a bootloader
on the MBR of the external USB hard-disk. This can be
done during installation or later.

> I tried it once with Ubuntu and Fedora but in vain. 

What did you try?

SK

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Dec 24 16:34:43 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Dec 24 16:35:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
Message-ID: <733621.1353.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

This is w.r.t. the thread at PLUG (Pune):
http://frodo.syminet.com/pipermail/plug-mail/2006-December/001484.html

on common questions like, "will I get job if I learn
linux", "who uses FOSS in the industry?". Its the
ignorance. Please follow the thread. So, I thought we
can start a project/wiki link called "I took the Red
pill" in our wiki: 

http://chennailug.org/wiki/?title=I_took_the_Red_Pill

with the following details:

1. Name.
2. Company/place where working
(Self/industry/academia).
3. Educational background (school/college/university).
4. FOSS domain.

It can mean either of the following:

1. It doesn't matter what you "study", but, you can
work on FOSS in the industry.

OR

2. I studied in the same school/college as you, and I
am currently working on FOSS (self or industry or
academia).

If you do not wish to mention the educational
background OR the company, that is ok. But, not both.
If you don't have a wiki account, but, would like to
add your details, please send me an e-mail, and your
details can be added. Or, get a wiki account to add
your details.

Background:
Morpheus in the Matrix [2] tells Neo: "This is your
last chance. After this, there is no turning back. You
take the blue pill - the story ends, you wake up in
your bed and believe whatever you want to believe. You
take the red pill - you stay in Wonderland and I show
you how deep the rabbit-hole goes. "

So, in our context, taking the red pill is getting to
know the truth or source code (free/open source).
Taking the blue pill would be just accepting the life
around with "trusted" closed-source, proprietary
systems.

Any thoughts/suggestions/feedback welcome.

SK

[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Pill

[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Matrix

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

Do You Yahoo!?
Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around 
http://mail.yahoo.com

Hello LUGies,

This is to inform you all that Me and Mr.Raman from ilug-chennai are 
handling a two day workshop for faculties of various colleges 
(Engineering and Non-engineering) at Sri Ramakrishna Engineering 
College, N.G.G,O Colony, Coimbatore -22 on 5th and 6th of January. The 
participants of this workshop can be Faculties from recognized colleges, 
research scholars from recognized colleges and representatives from 
Industries as well.

If you know some one who is interested to attend such a workshop, please 
ask them to contact Prof. K. Manoharan, HOD CSE Dept. Sri Ramakrishna 
Engineering College before 31st December to register for the workshop.
Phone numbers are: 0422-2460088, 2461588 and you can reach him through 
mail - mano_cbe@rediffmail.com.

To know more details about this workshop, please check 
http://srec.ac.in/ -- The pdf format of the invitation is available 
through the sidebar scrolling link of the event.

This workshop is organized by NRCFOSS, AU-KBC, Chennai and supported by 
representatives from ILUG-Chennai. We would be thankful if you can help 
us in taking such initiatives anywhere in India :)

From anant at kix.in  Sun Dec 24 18:44:20 2006
From: anant at kix.in (Anant Narayanan)
Date: Sun Dec 24 20:44:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <733621.1353.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <733621.1353.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <458E7D2C.9090405@kix.in>

> This is w.r.t. the thread at PLUG (Pune):
> http://frodo.syminet.com/pipermail/plug-mail/2006-December/001484.html

A very interesting thread indeed. One thing I am against though; and 
that is pushing universities to use FOSS (entirely).

Not wanting to start a flamewar or anything; but I feel that it is a 
university's responsibility to teach its CS student _everything_ there 
is to know about Computer Science in general. A university can _never_ 
officially endorse FOSS; simply because it does not form the software 
industry in its entirety; and I will also be bold enough to say that it 
forms only a small part of it.

Asking a university to stop using proprietary software is stupid. Not 
teaching CS students how to use Windows or Oracle is equally stupid. You 
need to teach students what is actually relevant in the world today; and 
I think we all accept the fact that there are many non-FOSS technologies 
that are still very prevalent in the industry.

What we must be actually pushing for is to dedicate atleast a little bit 
of the course towards FOSS. FOSS forms, say 20% of the software industry 
today; and a corresponding 20% of the time must be spent towards 
teaching it. But that's about it. Extremism will get us nowhere.

Just my 2 Paise ;)

--
Anant
From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Sun Dec 24 21:06:13 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan)
Date: Sun Dec 24 21:11:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <458E7D2C.9090405@kix.in>

Anant Narayanan wrote:
  > Not wanting to start a flamewar or anything; but I feel that it is a
> university's responsibility to teach its CS student _everything_ there 
> is to know about Computer Science in general. A university can _never_ 
> officially endorse FOSS; simply because it does not form the software 
> industry in its entirety; and I will also be bold enough to say that it 
> forms only a small part of it.
Again, not indulging in flame war or even an argument with my buddy, I 
add my single paisa!

What we are trying to (as from ilugc) is to give equal exposure to 
students about FOSS, as to what they were getting in Proprietary 
software. We always make sure to point out that we are not anti-M$ or 
anti-doze.

Its also necessary to teach them about FOSS because the teachers who 
have to teach the students about FOSS are themselves not pretty much 
aware of FOSS, so we have to take the first step.

If you have checked the last mail i sent a hour ago, this time we are 
dealing teachers and only teachers. So, may be what you say might happen 
  in future - i.e. FOSS aware teachers themselves teach students about 
FOSS and we are just trying to make that happen :)
> 
> Asking a university to stop using proprietary software is stupid. Not 
> teaching CS students how to use Windows or Oracle is equally stupid. You 
> need to teach students what is actually relevant in the world today; and 
> I think we all accept the fact that there are many non-FOSS technologies 
> that are still very prevalent in the industry.
> 
Giving them equal exposure in FOSS is our duty, and its then upto them 
to decide what they are going to embrace!

> What we must be actually pushing for is to dedicate atleast a little bit 
> of the course towards FOSS. FOSS forms, say 20% of the software industry 
> today; and a corresponding 20% of the time must be spent towards 
> teaching it. But that's about it. Extremism will get us nowhere.
> 
> Just my 2 Paise ;)

I agree, and thats what we are trying - awareness rather than conversion!

Here ends my single paisa! ;)

From binand at gmail.com  Sun Dec 24 22:59:42 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Dec 24 22:59:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <458E7D2C.9090405@kix.in>
References: <733621.1353.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com> <458E7D2C.9090405@kix.in>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612240929t117cc887k6f167f790d0e060c@mail.gmail.com>

On 24/12/06, Anant Narayanan <anant@kix.in> wrote:
> Asking a university to stop using proprietary software is stupid. Not
> teaching CS students how to use Windows or Oracle is equally stupid. You
> need to teach students what is actually relevant in the world today; and
> I think we all accept the fact that there are many non-FOSS technologies
> that are still very prevalent in the industry.

I cannot agree with this. Keeping in mind these are CS students, the
college's job is not to tech them HOW to use Windows or Oracle, but to
enable them to design tomorrow's Windows or Oracle. I really can't
agree to the argument that a compilers course can be taught equally
well with GCC and Visual Studio; or an RDBMS course with Postgres and
Oracle. A student of Automobile Engineering can look at a real world
car to learn the practical application of his/her theoretical
knowledge; why should a CS student be any different?

Binand
From anant at kix.in  Sun Dec 24 23:22:15 2006
From: anant at kix.in (Anant Narayanan)
Date: Sun Dec 24 23:48:24 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610612240929t117cc887k6f167f790d0e060c@mail.gmail.com>
References: <733621.1353.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com> <458E7D2C.9090405@kix.in>
	<d2a92d610612240929t117cc887k6f167f790d0e060c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <458EBE4F.2040207@kix.in>

> I cannot agree with this. Keeping in mind these are CS students, the
> college's job is not to tech them HOW to use Windows or Oracle, but to
> enable them to design tomorrow's Windows or Oracle.

You can't design something like Windows if you haven't used it. That's 
like making candy when you have never even tasted it. Corporates expect 
CS students to know how to use Windows and Oracle. Very few corporates 
expect the same about Linux and PostgreSQL.

What I'm saying is that you must treat all implementations of a 
particular concept _equally_. That's why Tanenbaum's book on Operating 
system considers both Windows and Linux as case studies. That's how it 
should be. You need to have both Windows and Linux based labs in a 
university with a ratio that reflects the real world (80-20?)

> I really can't
> agree to the argument that a compilers course can be taught equally
> well with GCC and Visual Studio; or an RDBMS course with Postgres and
> Oracle. A student of Automobile Engineering can look at a real world
> car to learn the practical application of his/her theoretical
> knowledge; why should a CS student be any different?

I'm not sure I understand your point here. Why can't you teach good C 
programming using Visual Studio? Why can't you teach good RDBMS concepts 
with Oracle? In an ideal case, as a CS student; I must know how to use 
both GCC _and_ Visual Studio. What the hell, I should even be taught to 
use XCode!

The bottom-line is that any university cannot "endorse" FOSS in any way; 
but merely "introduce" their students to it. Again, I remind you; FOSS 
forms a small part of the entire Software Industry; and must be treated 
like that; atleast from an academic perspective.

Yes; the electives designed by NRCFOSS is a good step in that direction. 
It's good to dedicate 2 courses to FOSS; but that's about it. We should 
not push for more; and never ever tell any university to remove Windows 
and put Linux in all their labs!

--
Anant
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Dec 25 00:22:37 2006

Hi,

Thanks for all your feedback.

--- Anant Narayanan <anant@kix.in> wrote:
> it. Corporates expect 
> CS students to know how to use Windows and Oracle.

Education, academia are to be *independant* of
corporate.

> Very few corporates 
> expect the same about Linux and PostgreSQL.

Too generic a statement.
 
> What I'm saying is that you must treat all
> implementations of a 
> particular concept _equally_. 

Concepts, true - independant of corporate
needs/requirements.

> You need to have both Windows and Linux
> based labs in a 
> university with a ratio that reflects the real world
> (80-20?)

That cannot be determined in reality.
 
> I'm not sure I understand your point here. Why can't
> you teach good C 
> programming using Visual Studio? 

We are dealing with concepts and methodologies. Use
programming languages as tools and tools only.

> FOSS 
> forms a small part of the entire Software Industry;

Incorrect. Statement not based on any facts. India is
one of the biggest consumers of free/open source
software [1]. David Axmark, co-founder of the MySQL
project also commented the same in his talk in
February 2006 [3].

> and must be treated 
> like that; atleast from an academic perspective.

Incorrect. You don't seem to have had exposure to
"real education" (like IIT, NITs) or education abroad.

Linux was an academia project.
 
> Yes; the electives designed by NRCFOSS is a good
> step in that direction. 

How can you tell?

*Designed* for theoretical, maybe. Something is better
than nothing. After interacting with students, I can
tell that implementation is not fruitful. Also find
review by Raman [2].

Message-ID: <d2a92d610612241115h6733e749r83162b173159e221@mail.gmail.com>

On 24/12/06, Anant Narayanan <anant@kix.in> wrote:
> > I really can't
> > agree to the argument that a compilers course can be taught equally
> > well with GCC and Visual Studio;
>
> I'm not sure I understand your point here. Why can't you teach good C
> programming using Visual Studio?

The point was not about teaching good C programming, but about
teaching compiler design.    Having GCC's source code available
expedites the student's understanding of compiler concepts, which
Visual Studio cannot provide (unless you sign up for one of those
shared source licenses).

The point was about CS students - who are expected to implement rather than use.

Binand
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Mon Dec 25 04:21:27 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Cartoons?
Message-ID: <20061224225127.GA27230@lakshmi.susmita.org>

Hi friends,

   First of all accept my warm wishes for Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year!

   http://girish1729.googlepages.com/wish.jpg

   Guess what is special about New Year?

   You can wish anybody irrespective of who they are in India.

   Anyway the purpose of this mail is not that.

   I drew this cartoon with tgif and a few images off the Internet.

   But all the images have been processed. You can recognize which image I have taken but the cartoon is my idea of course.

   It took only a trifling investment of time and effort. But the result I hope at least is satisfying.

   And of course, I don't have a Wacom tablet or anything. :)

   I just dropped the bunch of images I got into tgif.

   Cropped the parts I liked. I did lot of drawing on the bottom left image. You cannot make out I think that substantial effort has gone into making that image from the base image. And I fouled up the last image on the right just to make sure that I don't run into copyright issues...

   Anyway somehow I could quickly come up with a nice them,some verbiage and a few ellipses, arrows and text and I was done.

   I have got very few responses for this, but I love it.

   For the investment I put in the results are certainly impressive.

   Moral of the story, tgif is cool.

   gimp is not the only tool out there. ;)

   Wish you all a great 2007 guys!

   2006 is the year I discovered ILUGC.

   Or rather Bharathi helped me discover ILUGC...

   May 2007 bring you happiness, joy and prosperity to you.

   And fulfill all your desires.

   How many of you have resolved to become official developers this year?

   Or get into hacking seriously?

   Or better still , entrepreneurship?

   Wish you Godspeed!

   regards,
   Girish

Man,

	Can we avoid such "dangerous" remarks please?

	One depressing characteristic I have seen in many smart ppl is snobbishness and I have suffered a lot due to that in my college days.

	I used to get treated like a cigarette butt just because I was not good at scoring marks.

	But sometimes I find myself behaving snobbishly...

	I think it is the biggest bane of intellectuals worldwide.

	Please let us understand the brotherhood of man.

	"Each soul is potentially divine."

	Let us stand shoulder to shoulder and work for the benefit of our society, country and the world at large.

	We should promote excellence but not at the cost of being snobbish. I know it is hard but should be possible.

Best,
Girish

On 24-Dec-06, at 11:22 PM, Anant Narayanan wrote:

> The bottom-line is that any university cannot "endorse" FOSS in any  
> way; but merely "introduce" their students to it. Again, I remind  
> you; FOSS forms a small part of the entire Software Industry; and  
> must be treated like that; atleast from an academic perspective.
>
> Yes; the electives designed by NRCFOSS is a good step in that  
> direction. It's good to dedicate 2 courses to FOSS; but that's  
> about it. We should not push for more; and never ever tell any  
> university to remove Windows and put Linux in all their labs!

ideal is a platform neutral syllabus like MIT OCW. Given the level of  
teaching staff we have here, this would result in their taking the  
path of least resistance - proprietary software. So ideal wont work  
here. Although the very concept of foss electives is silly, we push  
it because it is needed to correct the existing bias. It is like  
reservations in admissions - not democratic, but necessary to correct  
past imbalances. And you cant really teach *anything* in depth unless  
you are able to pull it apart and examine how it works ...

> The point was not about teaching good C programming, but about
> teaching compiler design.    Having GCC's source code available
> expedites the student's understanding of compiler concepts, which
> Visual Studio cannot provide (unless you sign up for one of those
> shared source licenses).

What is wrong in seeing Visual Studio's code under Shared Source? One of 
the aims of Shared Source was to help the academia in understanding 
Microsoft's Code. Also, let me remind you that source code was always 
available to students and professors under several Microsoft Campus 
programs even before Shared Source came along.

In fact; I think it is an enriching experience to see both the source 
code of Visual Studio and GCC; to see two different angles of the 
implementation. There's a lot to be learnt from Visual Studio; really! 
Microsoft doesn't spend billions of dollars every year to produce junk 
code ;)

> The point was about CS students - who are expected to implement rather 
> than use.

Again, I say that you need to first use and then implement. You can't 
implement if you're not a master of usage :)

--
Anant

From anant at kix.in  Mon Dec 25 08:04:57 2006
From: anant at kix.in (Anant Narayanan)
Date: Mon Dec 25 08:40:36 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <20061224185237.89041.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>

Message-ID: <458F38D1.1000100@kix.in>

Hi Shakthi,

> Education, academia are to be *independant* of
> corporate.

Not at the undergraduate level. From mission statement of our 
college[1]: "To create technical manpower for meeting the current and 
future demands of industry."

>> Very few corporates 
>> expect the same about Linux and PostgreSQL.
> 
> Too generic a statement.

This is statistics from the field: 8 out of 10 companies wants working 
knowledge of the Windows OS when they come for campus recruiting; NOT Linux.

>> FOSS 
>> forms a small part of the entire Software Industry;
> 
> Incorrect. Statement not based on any facts. India is
> one of the biggest consumers of free/open source
> software [1]. David Axmark, co-founder of the MySQL
> project also commented the same in his talk in
> February 2006 [3].

Oh, so FOSS is now mainstream is it?! Folks at Slashdot will be very 
happy... C'mon; both you and I _know_ for a fact that FOSS does _NOT_ 
form the entire software industry; and it is far from it.

> Incorrect. You don't seem to have had exposure to
> "real education" (like IIT, NITs) or education abroad.
> 
> Linux was an academia project.

I am, in fact, from an NIT. Your (should I say snobbish) statement has 
greatly devalued yourself in my eyes; I would expect something more 
mature from a person of your stature.

Torvalds could have easily made Linux closed source; as easily as he 
made it free. He just happened to be the right person at the right time. 
Thousands of kernels (Linux quality) are produced from universities all 
over the world, every year..

> How can you tell?
> 
> *Designed* for theoretical, maybe. Something is better
> than nothing. After interacting with students, I can
> tell that implementation is not fruitful. Also find
> review by Raman [2].

The implementation was not followed up properly and that is the fault of 
the college; not NRCFOSS. When the same elective is implemented in my 
College; things will be _vastly_ different; I assure you.

Education should either be platform independent; or all platforms should 
be taught with equal vigor.

--
Anant

[1] http://www.mnit.ac.in/aboutmnit/mission.html

From anandsaha at gmail.com  Mon Dec 25 11:13:47 2006
From: anandsaha at gmail.com (Anand Saha)
Date: Mon Dec 25 11:13:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <458F38D1.1000100@kix.in>
References: <20061224185237.89041.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>
	<458F38D1.1000100@kix.in>
Message-ID: <154eca020612242143r6344ac23l788ba4fa6272eb17@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/25/06, Anant Narayanan <anant@kix.in> wrote:
> Not at the undergraduate level. From mission statement of our
> college[1]: "To create technical manpower for meeting the current and
> future demands of industry."
~
> This is statistics from the field: 8 out of 10 companies wants working
> knowledge of the Windows OS when they come for campus recruiting; NOT Linux.

>From a non-compsci pov:
In my college, the prod. and mech. students were taught designing
using AutoCad and ProE, because they are what the industry uses.
Also, Matlab was more prevelant than Scilab because of its ubiquity
and greater acceptance.

Technical prowess of the tool makes a bigger impact on selection of the
tool as a teaching aid, than how it is licensed or policy adopted.

So yes, I agree with you in that industry trend plays a role while
recommending a tool/suit as a teaching aid.

Things become a bit different when it comes to computer science,
as pointed by others.

However, in my opinion, this thread is comparing tools/software
to philosophy/licensing policy. Which leads to a great deal of confusion.
While Windows, Oracle and Visual Studios are software, FOSS is a
philosophy - a licensing policy. Yes FOSS does end with the word
'software', but in effect its a s/w is licensed, a way of thinking. So a
justified comparison cannot be made.

Technical capabilities of Windows should be compared to that of Linux.
GPL should be compared to EULA of MS.

saha
--

    In a FS env one can adapt an engine/interpreter from let's say lua, ruby ...

From vamlists at gmail.com  Mon Dec 25 12:02:00 2006
From: vamlists at gmail.com (Vamsee Kanakala)

Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <458F39DF.4010104@kix.in>
References: <733621.1353.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>	<458E7D2C.9090405@kix.in>	<d2a92d610612240929t117cc887k6f167f790d0e060c@mail.gmail.com>	<458EBE4F.2040207@kix.in>	<d2a92d610612241115h6733e749r83162b173159e221@mail.gmail.com>
	<458F39DF.4010104@kix.in>
Message-ID: <458F7060.8000405@gmail.com>

Anant Narayanan wrote:
> 
> What is wrong in seeing Visual Studio's code under Shared Source? 

I hope I'm not fanning a potential flame war, but some points need to be
made. Well, sure you see the code. You find a bug. You want to fix it.
You dutifully report it MS. Will it be fixed? When is it going to see
the light of the day? At least 6 months differential till you get the
VS.Net "update"? Why do I need to wait that long when I know how to fix
the problem? And do you really think they will accept a student's patch
into Windows source code?

> One of
> the aims of Shared Source was to help the academia in understanding
> Microsoft's Code. Also, let me remind you that source code was always
> available to students and professors under several Microsoft Campus
> programs even before Shared Source came along.
> 

Call me cynical, but Shared Source thing started being bandied about
pretty recently, and that too to counter FOSS insurgency in the
academia. I don't think it took off, and I don't think it will, which is
just as well.

> In fact; I think it is an enriching experience to see both the source
> code of Visual Studio and GCC; to see two different angles of the
> implementation. There's a lot to be learnt from Visual Studio; really!
> Microsoft doesn't spend billions of dollars every year to produce junk
> code ;)
> 

Warped logic. Spending billions of dollars is no guarantee of software
quality. You can get surprisingly good quality software with minimum
investment. At least, FOSS helps you do that.

>> The point was about CS students - who are expected to implement rather
>> than use.
> 
> Again, I say that you need to first use and then implement. You can't
> implement if you're not a master of usage :)
> 

Come on. You can use a software for years, become a "master user" in it,
and still not know how it actually works. You will know a lot about
automobiles by just taking apart a car than driving around for hours.


V.
From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Mon Dec 25 12:12:07 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Mon Dec 25 12:03:01 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <154eca020612242143r6344ac23l788ba4fa6272eb17@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20061224185237.89041.qmail@web50205.mail.yahoo.com>
	<458F38D1.1000100@kix.in>
	<154eca020612242143r6344ac23l788ba4fa6272eb17@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <2472D3D3-72BE-4AF9-B878-D60DE529A013@thenilgiris.com>


On 25-Dec-06, at 11:13 AM, Anand Saha wrote:

> However, in my opinion, this thread is comparing tools/software
> to philosophy/licensing policy. Which leads to a great deal of  
> confusion.
> While Windows, Oracle and Visual Studios are software, FOSS is a
> philosophy - a licensing policy. Yes FOSS does end with the word
> 'software', but in effect its a s/w is licensed, a way of thinking.  
> So a
> justified comparison cannot be made.

there are several issues here. Better companies would prefer to  
recruit people with programming skills rather that proficiency in  
specific tools. Lesser companies prefer proficiency in specific tools  
to general skills. A person proficient in oracle could become  
obsolete if oracle became obsolete - or if the company moved to a  
different RDBMS. But a person skilled in SQL would never become  
redundant. The problem is teachers - easy to teach a specific tool,  
difficult to teach a general skill. Colleges have to juggle - last  
thing anyone competent will become is a teacher. Companies have to  
juggle also.

secondly, licensing is the least part of foss. It is the development  
methodology that is the important part.
>
> Technical capabilities of Windows should be compared to that of Linux.
> GPL should be compared to EULA of MS.

dont forget, there are the BSD style licenses too which are just as  
foss as the GPL.

<rant>
why do people insist on saying FOSS == GPL
</rant>

-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Mon Dec 25 12:45:55 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)

Subject: [Ilugc] patch for mailing list guidelines
Message-ID: <55183E46-661D-4823-BCD9-CD310F6AAB41@thenilgiris.com>

I propose the following patch for http://chennailug.org/guidelines:

Instead of:
<snip>
Always use bottom-posting.

 > What is your name ?
My name is ILUGC.

</snip>

we should have:
<snip>
Always trim the post you are replying to and interleave your replies  
so that each part of the reply is under the quoted part that you are  
replying to. Further please leave a gap of one line between the  
matter you are quoting and your reply.

what is your name?
regards
xyz

trimmed and replied as:

 >what is your name?

my name is ilugc

and not as:

 >what is your name?
 >regards
 >xyz
my name is ilugc.

</snip>
-- 

regards
kg
http://lawgon.livejournal.com
http://nrcfosshelpline.in/web/

From vamlists at gmail.com  Mon Dec 25 13:30:14 2006
From: vamlists at gmail.com (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Mon Dec 25 13:30:29 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <458EBE4F.2040207@kix.in>
References: <733621.1353.qm@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>
	<458E7D2C.9090405@kix.in>	<d2a92d610612240929t117cc887k6f167f790d0e060c@mail.gmail.com>
	<458EBE4F.2040207@kix.in>
Message-ID: <458F850E.7040806@gmail.com>

Anant Narayanan wrote:
> 
> You can't design something like Windows if you haven't used it. 

Meh? Ever heard of the term "invention" or "innovation"? Why would I be
interested in re-inventing the wheel? Or being just as good as Windows
(and everyone knows how low the bar is) ?

> That's
> like making candy when you have never even tasted it. Corporates expect
> CS students to know how to use Windows and Oracle. Very few corporates
> expect the same about Linux and PostgreSQL.
> 

As Shakthi says, that's just too much generalization. Different
"corporates" need different kind of programmers. You are only looking at
the biggies here. If you care to research a little more, there are lots
of startups looking for good open source programmers, right here in India.

> What I'm saying is that you must treat all implementations of a
> particular concept _equally_. That's why Tanenbaum's book on Operating
> system considers both Windows and Linux as case studies. That's how it
> should be. You need to have both Windows and Linux based labs in a
> university with a ratio that reflects the real world (80-20?)
> 

Why should they? When the "learning potential" is more with FOSS, it is
perfectly appropriate to concentrate on/give more importance to that.
I'm sure a guy who can grok PostgreSQL very well will make a pretty good
Oracle programmer, maybe better than a guy who learnt just Oracle. I've
done both, so you're getting it from the horse's mouth.

> 
> I'm not sure I understand your point here. Why can't you teach good C
> programming using Visual Studio? Why can't you teach good RDBMS concepts
> with Oracle? In an ideal case, as a CS student; I must know how to use
> both GCC _and_ Visual Studio. What the hell, I should even be taught to
> use XCode!
> 

There is a reason Tanenbaum kept Minix that way - he wanted it to be
simple enough for students to hack on it. 'Nuff said.

> The bottom-line is that any university cannot "endorse" FOSS in any way;
> but merely "introduce" their students to it. Again, I remind you; FOSS
> forms a small part of the entire Software Industry; and must be treated
> like that; atleast from an academic perspective.
> 

I would say the university is either misinformed or just plain sissy. If
you believe teaching FOSS will benefit the students, there is nothing
wrong in endorsing it. And it's about time.


V.

On 25/12/06, Vamsee Kanakala <vamlists@gmail.com> wrote:
> I hope I'm not fanning a potential flame war, but some points need to be
> made. Well, sure you see the code. You find a bug. You want to fix it.
> You dutifully report it MS. Will it be fixed? When is it going to see

More than that, you invent a far more efficient optimization for
something - say pointer arithmetic - can you implement that in Visual
Studio and send the patches to a bunch of experts around the world for
review?

> > implementation. There's a lot to be learnt from Visual Studio; really!
> > Microsoft doesn't spend billions of dollars every year to produce junk
> > code ;)
>
> Warped logic. Spending billions of dollars is no guarantee of software
> quality. You can get surprisingly good quality software with minimum
> investment. At least, FOSS helps you do that.

Also, whether the code Microsoft produces is junk or not is still open
to debate. I personally think it is.

From binand at gmail.com  Mon Dec 25 15:20:39 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Mon Dec 25 15:20:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] problem with loop back device
In-Reply-To: <2d0135b0612250124i69c96af7oa8bda3ad730c56c6@mail.gmail.com>
References: <2d0135b0612250124i69c96af7oa8bda3ad730c56c6@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610612250150r508c28f4o9a0be31e8cc89127@mail.gmail.com>

On 25/12/06, ERGer <raju.apm@gmail.com> wrote:
> 1)i hav Fedora core 6 installed , where the default loop back device present
> is 8.if i create more upto 15 with necessary permissions as the existing
> ones for my own use and when i reboot it gets vanished.. why is this so?

Assuming you are talking about the loop device driver (and not the
loopback network interface), you can do:

modprobe loop max_loop=15

(Translating that into the format of /etc/modules.conf for persistence
across reboots left as an exercise)

Binand

Subject: [Ilugc] problem with pirut

I aint a FC user but found this from a simple google search.

http://staff.science.uva.nl/~hveerten/linux.html
says
"..
If pirut doesn't work after anymore after having removed the outdated
kernel, but gives the following error: *ERROR: Cannot find a valid baseurl
for repo: core *, type the following in a terminal:

rpm --rebuilddb
.."

From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Dec 26 14:23:37 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)
Date: Tue Dec 26 14:23:56 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Software to recover EXT3 partitions.
In-Reply-To: <4590D5B0.3000704@midascomm.com>
References: <4590D5B0.3000704@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <20061226085336.GA21090@lakshmi.susmita.org>

On Tue, Dec 26, 2006 at 01:26:32PM +0530, Sivaram wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> can someone name any software to recover data from a ext3 partitions?
> 
> the harddisk had Redhat 7.2 and the partition table seems to be corrupted.
> i booted with rescue disk, and did a fdisk -l, output is shown as total 
> harddisk is blank.
> 

There are several ways to boot and mount the partition of interest.

Perhaps the easiest is getting a liveCD.

Do a "fsck -y" or with some other flag and recover.

If fdisk goofs up nothing to worry. The partition table may be corrupt but your disk partition might be intact.

You can backup after booting into a USB keydrive or something.

In case you want to get the machine back to bootable state just install the appropriate bootblocks using grub.

#grub
 --> setup (hd,0) etc...

 Best of luck!

 regards,
 Girish
From girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com  Tue Dec 26 14:26:07 2006
From: girishvenkatachalam at gmail.com (Girish Venkatachalam)

I hope you are not running Apache inside chroot(1) jail.

For some reason mod_python is not loading. Perhaps you have to change the order in httpd.conf?

What is your line 54 and adjoining lines? Try changing the order and googling.

I have worked with the guts of Apache long ago but I don't recollect much right now. Yes, it is complex. :)

regards,
Girish

Sivaram wrote:
> the harddisk had Redhat 7.2 and the partition table seems to be
> corrupted. i booted with rescue disk, and did a fdisk -l, output is
> shown as total harddisk is blank.

Hmm., I'm not sure whether you have a program to do this., but.. if you
remember your partition structure (approximately atleast)., you can use
some hex-editors, etc.. to reconstruct the partition-table. But., not a
easy task. Will definitely ruin your happiness.

I think fdisk makes a copy of the partition-table somewhere else. Not
sure. Google should help with this.

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Tue Dec 26 15:28:16 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Tue Dec 26 15:27:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Using commercial IDE's for learning
Message-ID: <2008.61.247.255.57.1167127096.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

On 24/12/06, Anant Narayanan wrote:
>> I'm not sure I understand your point here. Why can't you teach good C
>> programming using Visual Studio?


>Because not many students can afford to buy licenses for using these
>at home? And also because many students might want to see the source
>code for the tools?
>
>Thanks.
>
>Kumar
>--
>Kumar Appaiah,

The IDE division of Borland is now a separate company called Codegear -
http://www.codegear.com. Turbo C++ is now available free, and so also
Turbo Delphi, Turbo C# etc. These tools can be used for learning and
commercial development too. If you want the better "professional
editions", they are available for about USD 250/a pop till the end of the
month.

The Visual Studio Express editions are also free. Again, they can be used
for commercial development.

Thanks,
PK

Hi All.

   I''ve installed j2sdk1.4.2_12 &  jakarta-tomcat-5.0.30 under /usr/local/
directory my LAMP version is Apache-1.3.37,MySQL-5.0.27,PHP-4.4.3.
when i tried to install php-java-bridge-3.2.1 under /usr/local/ directory at
the compilation i'm getting the bugs

This is the steps which i followed (php-java-bridge is a tar ball downloaded
the domain)

root@vasu [/usr/local/php-java-bridge-3.2.1]# rpm --import RPM-GPG-KEY

root@vasu [/usr/local/php-java-bridge-3.2.1]# phpize
Configuring for:
PHP Api Version:         20020918
Zend Module Api No:      20020429
Zend Extension Api No:   20050606

root@vasu [/usr/local/php-java-bridge-3.2.1]# ./configure
--with-java=/usr/loca l/j2sdk1.4.2_12

root@vasu [/usr/local/php-java-bridge-3.2.1]# make

libnatcJavaBridge.la)
source='php/java/bridge/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.java'
object='php/java/bridge/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.o' libtool=no \
depfile='php/java/bridge/.deps/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.Po'

tmpdepfile='php/java/bridge/.deps/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.TPo' \
depmode=gcc3 /bin/sh ./depcomp \
gcj -fjni -g -O2 -c -o php/java/bridge/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.o `test
-f 'php/java/bridge/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.java' || echo

'./'`php/java/bridge/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.java
./php/java/bridge/Util.java:437: Type `StackTraceElement' not found in the
declaration of the local variable `stack'.
            StackTraceElement stack[] =
throwable.getStackTrace();
               ^
./php/java/bridge/JavaBridge.java:481: Type `StackTraceElement' not found
in the declaration of the local variable `trace'.
        StackTraceElement[] trace =
e.getStackTrace();
           ^
2 errors
make[1]: *** [php/java/bridge/Base64EncodingOutputBuffer.o] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory `/usr/local/php-java-bridge-3.2.1/server'
make: *** [/usr/local/php-
java-bridge-3.2.1/modules/stamp] Error 2

root@vasu [/usr/local/php-java-bridge-3.2.1]#

Date: Tue Dec 26 16:53:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Software to recover EXT3 partitions.
In-Reply-To: <4590D5B0.3000704@midascomm.com>
References: <4590D5B0.3000704@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <1f67acaf0612260323m4a790e22y4f0e856a0115f344@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/26/06, Sivaram <sivaramsk@midascomm.com> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> can someone name any software to recover data from a ext3 partitions?
>
> the harddisk had Redhat 7.2 and the partition table seems to be corrupted.
> i booted with rescue disk, and did a fdisk -l, output is shown as total
> harddisk is blank.
>
well, if you had acidentally deleted partitions (only the  partition
table entries are reset )and you did not zero the filesystem entries
(which sane people can't ;-) )

Testdisk is there to save your life :)
www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk
pickup a liveCD and and run testdisk. and recover the partition table
or the files from it.

From navalady at gmail.com  Tue Dec 26 22:55:51 2006
From: navalady at gmail.com (nava ladi)
Date: Tue Dec 26 22:56:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] problem with loop back device
In-Reply-To: <e597802d0612250449l13a9b281gebaf4c0ed26ce728@mail.gmail.com>
References: <2d0135b0612250124i69c96af7oa8bda3ad730c56c6@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610612250150r508c28f4o9a0be31e8cc89127@mail.gmail.com>
	<e597802d0612250449l13a9b281gebaf4c0ed26ce728@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d05619590612260925rab04a84wae02d0beed2385ae@mail.gmail.com>

This ll help u,

Edit the /etc/conf.d/rc file

# UDEV OPTION:
# Set to "yes" if you want to save /dev to a tar ball on shutdown
# and restore it on startup.  This is useful if you have a lot of
# custom device nodes that udev does not handle/know about.

RC_DEVICE_TARBALL="yes"

Do this after u created all loop device files,it ll be saved &
restored when u boot every time.

Regards,
Navaladi A

On 12/26/06, Suresh Ramasubramanian <linux@frodo.hserus.net> wrote:
> ????? ????? ?????? ?????? Vivek Iyyer wrote:
> > I am too lazy to do this. I get a nice little window asking me about

> > forementioned form) and the key system(open system or shared key).
>
> Got all that. Only problem is .. how the hell do I bring it up as soon
> as kde starts. Not by opening the network manager from my menu, bringing
> up that profile and clicking activate?

Using network-manager on GNOME and I'm not creating any profiles like
what you mention. I just start gnome-session , network-manager applet
loads and finds the Access-Points. I just click on the applet, see the
AP's available and click on the one which I want to connect to.

Have you disabled networking startup scripts (/etc/network/interfaces)
? network-manager needs to manage the network interfaces and
ifup/ifconfig should not be doing it.

Hi srs,

On 12/27/06, Suresh Ramasubramanian <linux@frodo.hserus.net> wrote:
> Works just fine with or without network-manager (which is a frontend to
> /etc/network/interfaces etc) .. IF i dont have wep etc profiles setup

Are we talking about the same "NetworkManager" here ?
The one I'm talking about is [1][2]. GNOME's 'Network Settings' is a
frontend for /etc/network/interfaces.

[1] http://www.gnome.org/projects/NetworkManager/
[2] http://www.redhat.com/magazine/003jan05/features/networkmanager/

The NetworkManager I'm using is not linked to /etc/network/interfaces
in any way.

-Toufeeq

Hi,

On 12/27/06, Suresh Ramasubramanian <linux@frodo.hserus.net> wrote:
> Toufeeq Hussain wrote:
> > [1] http://www.gnome.org/projects/NetworkManager/
> > [2] http://www.redhat.com/magazine/003jan05/features/networkmanager/
> >
> > The NetworkManager I'm using is not linked to /etc/network/interfaces
> > in any way.
>
> oh right - the kde analogue of network settings
> am on ubuntu - have to see about using networkmanager

Ah, do give NetworkManager a try. Removes the WEP/WPA hassles out of
the way when it comes to Wi-Fi access.

For kde there's network-manager-kde which is a systray applet which
does the authentication and takes care of maintaining the link. Even
supports (limited) VPN connectivity. :)

-Toufeeq

lost pictures (Photo Recovery) from digital camera memory. try this :)

Message-ID: <loom.20061227T145642-222@post.gmane.org>

Ganesh K.B. <kbganesh.iitm@...> writes:

> Anybody got any idea what they mean by "technically feasible" thats listed?

well, it has to do with the cable length - or the signal loss in the cable or
the cable resistance etc. a characteristic loss of 60 db or cable length of
about 6km is good for about 512kbps. if the loss is about 40 db or cable length
of around 3km, one can get 2-3 mbps and so on. of course, the cable lengths
depend on the wire gauge used - if thicker wires are used, the distances will of
course be more. these are typical values; i have run a 2mbps link over a 6+ km
cable without any problem - this was iitm's first broadband connection some 5-6
years ago.

sriram

On Wed, Dec 27, 2006 at 02:09:14PM +0000, p. sriram wrote:
> Ganesh K.B. <kbganesh.iitm@...> writes:
> 
> > Anybody got any idea what they mean by "technically feasible" thats listed?
> 
> well, it has to do with the cable length - or the signal loss in the cable or
> the cable resistance etc. a characteristic loss of 60 db or cable length of
> about 6km is good for about 512kbps. if the loss is about 40 db or cable length
> of around 3km, one can get 2-3 mbps and so on. of course, the cable lengths
> depend on the wire gauge used - if thicker wires are used, the distances will of
> course be more. these are typical values; i have run a 2mbps link over a 6+ km
> cable without any problem - this was iitm's first broadband connection some 5-6
> years ago.

I have no practical exp playing with this sorta stuff but I will give my two cents.

Purity of copper is key and quality of terminations. Usually telephone cables are supposed to have 99.99999 % purity. And cable thickness is a mute point as telephone grade cables have constant thickness.

It is a simple very thin two wire cable. However theoretically at least transmission lines have infinite bandwidth and it is amazing that telephones lines so thin are able to give such a high bandwidth.

Signal loss as mentioned above, Shannon's information theory signal to noise ratio fundas and few other factors complicate calculations.

But since the last mile of most urban areas don't go beyond a few couple of kilometres at most and mostly AFAIK it is a ring topology. Logically it is a star with all lines ending on the exchange switch but I heard that physically it is some kind of a ring.

Anyway I guess BSNL will be able to meet the promise without much trouble in spite of all these factors...

regards,
Girish

Date: Thu Dec 28 11:45:34 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] copper wire and stuff
References: <1228.61.247.255.58.1166249991.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>
	<4f41aad80612212225n13b2eco12adb40e724f49bf@mail.gmail.com>
	<e0900f3e0612212301k713258e2t4d57f4d515a42cf6@mail.gmail.com>
	<1f869bdd0612221403r2c2a7b04w200839ef255af66f@mail.gmail.com>
	<4f41aad80612260714jaf33e87h1981894635ca3bd0@mail.gmail.com>
	<6be355de0612270245r7b4bcabbgae991429ea631c40@mail.gmail.com>
	<5c56c21b0612270416q29c87767off8eb55e33cb19d5@mail.gmail.com>
	<loom.20061227T145642-222@post.gmane.org>
	<20061227143722.GA5150@lakshmi.susmita.org>
Message-ID: <loom.20061228T062552-528@post.gmane.org>

Girish Venkatachalam <girishvenkatachalam@...> writes:

> I have no practical exp playing with this sorta stuff but I will give my two 
> cents.

two cents of speculation? why??

> Purity of copper is key and quality of terminations. Usually telephone cables 
> are supposed to have 99.99999 % purity. And cable thickness is a mute point as 
> telephone grade cables have constant thickness.

that would be called 7N copper and i believe any phone company that tries to use
such wire would go broke quite quickly. standard conductor grade copper is
99.45% copper, typical for power applications; communications applications could
use higer purity copper. but even audiophiles (freaks) might use 7N copper
cables in studio applications, not for telephone wire. cable thickness is not a
moot point; unless you have recently laid wire (laid in last 10 years), you may
find different thicknesses. current 'standard' telephone wire is 26 gauge or
0.4mm dia. even now, us telephone cos are reverting to the older 24 gauge 0.5mm
dia wires. 24 gauge wire can be approximately 50% longer than 26 gauge for the
same resistance. 20 year plus cables may even be 22 gauge. even if you have
fresh connection, part of the cable path will be old (or very old) wires and
possibly of different gauge. thats why we have the catch-all 'technical
feasibility'. incidentally, when iitm first wanted the 2mbps connection, the
telephone folks went by the cable distance they had on their charst and refused
it as technically not feasible. since we knew that much of the cable was decades
old, we figured it would actually work; a resistance measurement pointed the
same way and it took off from there. yeah, with old age comes the propensity for
telling stories ...

sriram

>> Not at the undergraduate level. From mission
>> statement of our 
>> college[1]: "To create technical manpower for
>> meeting the current and 
>> future demands of industry."
> 
> That is what we are saying is wrong and bad ... (1)

Good or bad, that's the current system. Feel free to attempt any 
changes. I for one, would love it if my university didn't worry about 
the industry when they form the curriculum; but sadly, that's how it is 
and we have to live with it.

> I already posted a link to my databases. As a student,
> you don't get exposure to the industry in India. That
> is a pity, and that is something that I address in my
> "Careers with GNU/Linux" talk.

Can't wait to attend your talk. However, from what knowledge I have of 
the industry (from the perspective of campus placement); I derive that 
none of the "biggies": IBM, Microsoft or Google make any assumptions for 
knowledge of GNU/Linux at the undergraduate level.

Your database lists companies that merely "use" FOSS. That's not what 
I'm really interested in; because even Microsoft uses a lot of GNU/Linux 
and has demands for people experienced in those fields. Google is no 
different that what Microsoft does; as in all their products are still 
proprietary. They might use a little more FOSS than Microsoft but that's 
where the dissimilarity ends. And in any case, none of the companies you 
list assume any prior knowledge of GNU/Linux (I have directly enquired 
with Infosys, Google, AMD, CTS, HP & IBM: all of these are visiting my 
campus this April). They will teach the recruits FOSS during training if 
you are assigned a job in that area.

What I'm really interested in is the list of companies that actually 
"produce" FOSS and thereby directly contributing to its growth. 
Companies like Red Hat and Deeproot Linux. However, I cannot, in good 
conscience; advise my peers to only take jobs in those companies, simply 
because they do not offer a payscale that can match any of the 
"biggies". Why must a B.Tech. student settle for anything less, when 
Microsoft is offering a salary of Rs. 12 lakh an annum?

> You are an exception for a person from NIT. I feel
> sorry for you.

Too personal a comment.

Let me reiterate that the thoughts I posted before are directly from the 
Director of our college; when we discussed implementing the course on 
FOSS with him. You don't need to convince me of the benefits of FOSS; 
but I am at a loss convincing my director and do believe that there is 
some truth in what he says.

Endorsing FOSS to its fullest will have drastic effects not only for the 
NIT's but also the IIT's given that there is a _lot_ interdependence 
between these institutions and the industry. Microsoft and Google offer 
the best intellectual challenges & paychecks a B. Tech. can ever dream 
of; and when they don't want you to know FOSS; why the extra effort?

I know, that's a typical Indian attitude; but that's how it is.

--
Anant

money/fame.

lateral thinking. You have to think of ways by which
you can learn when you are put in a restricted
environment, such as a college. How about using a
computer at home, or if the college provides few
computers, how can you utilize it to the maximum for
your needs.

FOSS community can guide you ... (1)

If it is your (the students') future, you have to work
for it.

References: <592958.21144.qm@web50212.mail.yahoo.com> <459370E1.9000505@kix.in>
Message-ID: <e70ef6930612280043g6982d508ha631ac08de9a30aa@mail.gmail.com>

> Your database lists companies that merely "use" FOSS. That's not what
> I'm really interested in; because even Microsoft uses a lot of GNU/Linux
> and has demands for people experienced in those fields. Google is no
> different that what Microsoft does; as in all their products are still
> proprietary. They might use a little more FOSS than Microsoft but that's
> where the dissimilarity ends. And in any case, none of the companies you
> list assume any prior knowledge of GNU/Linux (I have directly enquired
> with Infosys, Google, AMD, CTS, HP & IBM: all of these are visiting my
> campus this April). They will teach the recruits FOSS during training if
> you are assigned a job in that area.
>

Do you want Google to release their Search Engine Code ? What matters
is not the code, but how the ranking works. It(pagerank) is patented
by Google and you can easily get to know more about that by searching
for it (in Google)

Google supports FOSS and also releases many Open Source projects.
Take a look at http://code.google.com/projects.html

Google's Summer of Code program encourages students to develop for OSS
projects and also provide $4500. It was conducted for the past 2
years.

is what saddens me.

> Do you want Google to release their Search Engine Code ? What matters
> is not the code, but how the ranking works. It(pagerank) is patented
> by Google and you can easily get to know more about that by searching
> for it (in Google)

No doubt that Google is more "FOSS-friendly" than MS. But that is not 
enough. FOSS will not be completely victorious until there is a 
billion-dollar MNC backing it. Red Hat and Novell are trying; it might 
be a while until they get there.

Google is also taking steps to open source some of its code (GWT for 
example); and there is a lot more it can do: Google Earth; Google Talk 
are all applications that are ripe candidates for FOSS based licensing.

> Google's Summer of Code program encourages students to develop for OSS
> projects and also provide $4500. It was conducted for the past 2
> years.

I took part in the 2006 edition. They also give a free T-Shirt ;)

be addressed from an industry perspective, or another
approach. For example, through install-fests or
workshops.

The students that I have seen in India live in their
own shell. So, at that age with lack of real-world
exposure, they think that they know everything, and
they don't realize that. You are an exception because
you have had the exposure of FOSS, and you have been
working on it really well. 

So, there has to be a turning point for your peers.
But, when it happens, there is no looking back. Trust
me on this one.
 
> skills when facing the 
> interview doesn't seem to help in any visible
> manner. 
> All they really 
> care about is your CGPA. I am saying this because I
> have personally 
> experienced it :(

That is a problem in India. Even though I was an MS,
and I had six years domain experience in Free
Software, (prior to starting work in India), the HR
called me a "fresher". WTF? But, I moved on. To me
work was more important, not designation. You know HR
are ignorant, and they will not understand anything
that you talk. So, why waste your energy.

> you get the job or not!

>>
>> > Do you want Google to release their Search Engine Code ?
>>
>> yes - would love it
>>
> 
> Me too. 

The next best thing:

http://lucene.apache.org/nutch/

> But wouldn't it help Black Hat SEOs to work on getting their
> sites top on the search results?

It's other way round - it would help defeat Black Hat SEOs because the
algorithm is open-source, and likely to be much more bullet-proof than
the closed-source ones. Jimmy Wales, founder of Wikipedia is already
taking a shot at it:

http://mashable.com/2006/12/23/wikiasari-wikipedia-founder-launching-a-google-rival/

http://googlesystem.blogspot.com/2006/12/wikiasari-open-search-engine.html

Perhaps not very surprisingly, Wikiasari uses Nutch and Lucene heavily.


V.

From goda.abishek at gmail.com  Fri Dec 29 08:47:13 2006
From: goda.abishek at gmail.com (Ingeneur)
Date: Fri Dec 29 08:47:23 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC] "I took the Red Pill" project/wiki site
In-Reply-To: <20061228120733.11965.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <459387D7.3080201@kix.in>
	<20061228120733.11965.qmail@web50210.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <70106e0b0612281917u75838425o9d156e3a61234cbe@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

>> Engineering teams?? What are these?
> The real technical folks in a company?
Amen. This raises an interesting question. How technical should the
technical folk in a company be? In my opinion, only as technical to
understand what the company is already producing. For everyone else,
the job is a lot less challenging especially if the idea of technical
expertise and engineering is not just understanding what is there but
try a hand at innovation and change. Companies are mostly never meant
to accept huge changes unless the market warrants one. Thats my
opinion.

> I agree. I appreciate your efforts in this regard.
> Somethings that can't be done at a student-level can
> be addressed from an industry perspective, or another
> approach. For example, through install-fests or
> workshops.

That reminds of an interesting quote from one Hamming's lecture (or
speech). Toufeeq had written about it in his blog. To quote,
"The day your vision, what you think needs to be done, is bigger than
what you can do single-handedly, then you have to move toward
management. And the bigger the vision is, the farther in management
you have to go. You can't make it happen from the bottom very easily."

> Some people learn in the later part of their lives ...

At which point the learning might seem futile!!

-- 
Regards,

Abishek Goda
http://abishek.wetpaint.com

Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Kurukshetra Online Programming Contest

Hey guys,

College of Engineering, Guindy[1] announces the Kurukshetra[2] Online
Programming Contest[3] as a part of it's Inter-departmental Tech. Fest, 
Kurukshetra. The event is your opportunity to compete with the World's 
best coders with algorithm-centric problems that will rattle your grey 
matter!

The event is to be held on December 31th and is open to ALL (Working 
professionals and students). So how does it work? A set of problems will 
be posted on the website. You code the solution and submit it to the 
server. The server evaluates your solution (so make sure the output 
formats are right).

Date: 31-December-2006 (yup new years party indeed!)
Timings : 14:00hrs IST[4] - 20:00 hrs IST
Max. Team Size : 3 (lone wolves allowed too)
Languages Allowed: C, C++, Java, Python, Ruby, Perl, C#

Prizes Worth *2000 USD*!!
Visit http://opc.kurukshetra.org.in/accounts/register/ and register for 
the event.
-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

P.S All attempts at passing on the information will be appreciated :-)

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:

Thanks :-)

And just to add some relevant information. The site runs on a LAMP 
server. The web application Hackzor[1] uses Django[2].

Hackzor is a distributed Programming Contest Judge written in Python and 
Django. It uses a Client-Server Arch to improve scalability. (We expect 
thousands of ppl to be accessing the site on D-Day).

-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

[1] http://code.google.com/p/hackzor/
[2] http://www.djangoproject.com/

> how does a client-server architecture improve scalability? Scalability
> over what other architecture?

Heh. I suppose what that means is that the uploaded contest entries
are passed onto a different box to compile/run against test
data/score, so that the main box is free to serve visitors.

Incidentally, the problems on the website are about very elementary
algorithms - I hope the main contest will be of a higher standard? For
example, see this one:

http://opc.kurukshetra.org.in/opc/problems/2/

Unless I'm missing something, all it takes is to sort the input
numbers in descending order (qsort(3)) and spit out elements 0, 1 & 2
of the resultant array?

From prashmohan at gmail.com  Sat Dec 30 01:41:06 2006
From: prashmohan at gmail.com (Prashanth Mohan)
Date: Sat Dec 30 01:41:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] Kurukshetra Online Programming Contest
In-Reply-To: <45954BEE.3060501@gmail.com>
References: <4594D60C.4000000@gmail.com>	<4C71AB03-F8EE-4A00-B711-137591EBE562@thenilgiris.com>	<4594ED0E.8050706@gmail.com>
	<45954BEE.3060501@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4595765A.9090409@gmail.com>

Vamsee Kanakala wrote:
> Interesting. Since it's marked OT anyways, can you explain what you mean
> by "client-server arch" and how it would help you scale? Just curious...

I am guessing Binand's mail answered the main part of the question. The 
compilation, running and output checking is offloaded to distributed 
clients.

The part to be considered is this. The compilation+running (against test 
input)+checking output could constitute about 5-10 seconds of execution 
time. This would put an unnecessary strain on the webserver. *If* we 
reach the kind of load that we expect, then service could be really hit 
by having a single evaluator (or so we speculate). Having multiple 
clients evaluating the attempts in a distributed manner cleans up a lot 
of the mud :-)

-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com
From prashmohan at gmail.com  Sat Dec 30 01:47:17 2006
From: prashmohan at gmail.com (Prashanth Mohan)

Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:
> Unless I'm missing something, all it takes is to sort the input
> numbers in descending order (qsort(3)) and spit out elements 0, 1 & 2
> of the resultant array?

apparently not as simple. You need to the maximum 3 elements and minimum 
2 elements under consideration :-).

But yes. We promise to have much harder problems on the day of the contest.

Part of the reason for allowing different languages (including 4th gen 
languages) is that we don't expect the users to derive much help from 
the libraries solving these questions. An irksome factor that you face 
in most Online Programming Contest environments such as MIPT[1], UVA[2], 
etc are that they dont allow for languages such as Python, etc. They 
restrict themselves to C, C++, and Java. The language often turns out to 
be a limiting factor on your creativity.

It will be a test of your brains.. believe me on that :-)
-- 
Prashanth Mohan
http://prashblog.com

[1] http://acm.mipt.ru/judge/problems.pl
[2] http://acm.uva.es/problemset/

>
>
>
> You miss out something.. It can contain negative numbers. The product of
> two
> negative numbers is positive. Imagine the sequence 2,5,1.4.9.2000
> ,-1000,-2500.
> Here ur algo would give 2000,9,5 as output. but what about the sequence
> -2500,-1000,2000?
>
> But still i think its an easy algortihm , shouldnt take more than 2
minutes to think of for any computer student
1.Split into positive and negative number arrarys
2.Sort both in ascending order
3.1st number from sorted positive numbers is always taken
4.product of n2*n3 from positive numbers array and n1*n2 from negative
numbers array is computued and which ever is greater those values are
taken.
in your example , 2000 wil be taken first , and since -1000*-2500 is greater
than 9*4 , -1000 and -2500 will be taken.
